author: {'steamid': '76561198081281137', 'num_games_owned': 539, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 191, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1711680069}

author: {'steamid': '76561198103828417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1623, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1711906849}
review:
As a new game designer, this game is really inspiring and really well done. The spell-crafting is so intuitive and very intricate to make whatever spell you need. If you want a game that brings back a nostalgia type feel, give this game a try.

11/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198037627054', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1711243808}
review: Sadly, the gameplay in this title is just not good enough to carry it, and the design of the game is... well, bad. It has great ideas with it's spellcrafting, but the actual spells you can use don't feel fun. Combat cycles between a tedious chore, and a tedious bloodbath as you get attacked from every angle. When facing multiple enemies, I would get destroyed but not in a fun or engaging way; just got overwhelmed by attacks and my character is too sluggish to actually respond and block or dodge in time. Then I got to the first proper boss, a giant ent-like creature. His animations took so long that most of the fight I was just waiting for him to perform his next completely predictable move. It is just not engaging at all which is sad because I feel like the spell system deserves better mechanics than this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066817084', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 667, 'last_played': 1711132374}
review:
Great ideas, poor execution. Story is meh.
Gameplay is build on experimentation, but experimenting is too tideous, as is switching between spells (of same category). Also, some spells are just OP desensivizing further testing and degenenerate the game into Walk-and-Gun.
Status effects (on self) are poorly visible. You can easely get StunLocked by enemies with little counter.
Respawnpoints are too far from medium boss encounters.
Unskippable cutscenes!
And other poor design choices.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031793876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1710756594}
review: Pretty chill, but also a surprisingly in-dept magic system, having a lot of fun, pretty damn good indie game, would buy from this studio again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198082202614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1710171490}
review: Top

author: {'steamid': '76561197983999471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1707334917}
review:
I like the game a lot. For me the best part is that you can build your own spells. You can experiment and discover very different behaviors and outcomes of the spells.
The story is nice but nothing very special or new. The world is nice designed and the controlls worked well for me.
If you like magic based games with some nice riddles and you like experimenting with magic I can fully recommend this game.
So why are you still reading my review instead of playing it by yourself? :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197986241261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1705973868}
review: A quick, charming adventure with a really cool spell craft mechanic use to solve in world puzzles and increase combat efficiency. Has a balanced level of metroidvania style exploration and back tracking, plenty of puzzles and secrets to upgrade your spellcraft arsenal. 8/10 well worth at normal price, a must have on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008251892', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1705585417}
review:
Good things first - it is beutifull, and interesting. 

But it need to be more humane. 
DO NOT satrt this game on arch-mage, i repeat - do not. It is not medium difficulty, it is hardcore, and you can not change it back mid-game. 
And it is not like souls-difficult(i completed all souls and lies of p), it is "controls is awful" dificult. Prolly i could have more fun if it was not that hard, but i dont want to replay from the start. 

Devs have this sadistic set of design patterns:
1) when you get hit - you not only loose HP - you get stunlocked 
2) every boss spawns horde of small enemies to do it to you. 
3) You do not have properly working roll-dodge, and a dash-spell aimed at your target and feels awful in combat. 
4) You can not change difficulty if you hit a wall
All of this design choices are not bad inherently, but in combination - they are frustrating as hell, probably it will work if they fix at least one of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000942469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1705021057}
review:
Mages of Mystralia is one of those unique but deeply flawed experiences that are very audience-specific. If you're looking for polish and quality you won't find it here. If you're looking for something not quite like anything you've played before, this is one of your few options.

First, let's get the standard stuff out of the way. The graphics are hideous, the music forgettable, the controls are responsive but don't feel great, and the game's pacing is a bit odd.

The game's flagship feature, designing your own spells, is the crux. I lied a bit when I said it was "unique" -- it bears some similarity to build choices in Path of Exile or the ancient Genesis game Jewel Master -- but it's pretty close. It's not perfect by any means. Sometimes it doesn't do what you expect. Some mechanics are never explained. The UI for creating spells is a bit wonky. But the key feature, thoughtfully designing spells for different situations and using your tools cleverly, is there. If you don't spend time thinking about your spells, you simply won't finish the game. Coming up with an effective spell and using it to blow through content is a great feeling. It's not just fun, it's a type of fun you won't really find anywhere else.

So would I recommend Mages of Mystralia? Yeah, I would. More importantly, I'd recommend keeping an eye on its developers' future efforts, and I'd recommend other game designers look to it for inspiration. It may not be award-winning quality, but it is memorably novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086681617', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1705071495}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045479630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1705431484}
review:
a charming, creative gem that deserves a lot more attention. Check it out if it seems even mildly interesting to you.
Edit: if you're struggling with the early game, try to push on until you get the explosion spell at the sky temple. That's where the game really kicks off.

Mages of Mystralia is a fantanstic short adventure game which comes with a variety of puzzles and magic abilities to defeat many enemy types. The combat is fun and fluid but the best part about the game is the spell combination builder which is so well crafted and really adds a lot of customisation to the abilities you can use.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1703319334}
review:
"Mages of Mystralia" is a mediocre console ported low poly 3D rendered 2D top down shooter with lightweight RPG/adventure elements.  It's narrative driven, which is good, but the narrative is really lame, which is bad.  This is coupled with some lazy low poly "art" instead of contemporary graphics, poor control scheme, and a gimmick where you "create" spells ala games like Magicka, but in this implementation it's poorly thought out and generally imbalanced, making the game generally un-fun to play. 

There's also the annoying aspect that the developers took a lazy copout and all the characters speak "Simlish", like from Maxis/EA's The Sims.  It made sense in The Sims, here, the narrative being random babbling is just irritating.  I don't understand why they couldn't just use voice actors.  I don't know if that's better or worse than using a text-to-speech, either, but I guess the point is, there's a lot of laziness in the implementation here that doesn't warrant the frankly ridiculous price tag for this insulting console port. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The game features lazy low-polygon "retro" assets, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the mid 2000s.  It's unclear why the developers weren't able to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets for the game, and also irrelevant... what matters is that this looks bad as a result of their decisions, a compromise PC gamers shouldn't have to put up with.

PC gamers will be insulted by the demand from the developer that a console peasant children's toy controller should be used, despite this being on PC.  Developers should try to be aware which platform they're developing for, and must never, under any circumstances dictate to gamers how their games are to be experienced.

Another defect in the game caused by the console-peasant-centric design is the intolerably bad camera controls.  There's no effective mouselook, and control of the viewing angles is deliberately outside of reasonable control from the user.

This defect springs from the limitations of inferior console peasant children's toy gamepads, but on PC we don't have this limitation due to KB+M controls... however, the developer deliberately chose to arrogantly foist this handicap onto PC gamers.  Out of spite, or laziness, it's unclear, regardless, once more console peasants and console devs have made gaming worse for everyone.

Because this is designed for consoles, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the inferior console gaming appliances that the game was designed for.  These are unfortunate compromises and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was a second thought for the console-centric developers.  The game is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for consoles forces upon a game.  Once more, console peasants have made gaming worse for everyone.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

"Mages of Mystralia" has the utterly unrealistic price of $20 USD, for which you could easily get any number of older AAA games.  Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.  For comparison, the $20 asking price for this game could get you games like "Bioshock Infinite", "Lethal Company" or "Frostpunk".  Quality, professionally made games like those are frequently on sale cheaper than this.  There's also thousands of free, superior quality games on Steam.

review:
Want to just chill and do some nice platformer + puzzle game?
I cat totally recommend trying this one.

100% completed the whole game in a bit under 10 hours, enjoyed almost all of it.
Was a bit frustrated with the running around until i figured out that you can (and should) fix it with magic:
[spoiler] Craft a dash -> Ego + Move + Duration (optional - makes it longer and faster)  [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198022183279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1693007855}
review:
The Bad:
* The controls, casting a spell makes you stand still for a LONG time, but enemies WILL keep attacking with ranged & melee.
* The puzzles aren't about thought, but timing which is terrible when the controls suck
* The translation to English is very bad
* The story is REALLY bad
* The quest objects make no sense
* The music is forgettable
* The game opens with back to back fetch quests and grinding large amounts of currency
* Boss fights aren't fun, just annoying
* There's no teleportation. Get ready for lots of obnoxious backtracking.

The Worst:
* Combat, this is by FAR the worst part. I'll break it down.
A) Every fight is against mobs of enemies. They have melee, ranged, CC, and they all gang up on you.
B) All of your attacks deal very little damage
C) For the first 45 minutes your only decent attack is melee that requires you to be within hugging range. The basic goblin has double your reach.
D) All of your attacks root you in place for a LONG time, including the melee
E) You have a stamina bar. Literally everything except moving consumes stamina
F) You have to choose between a dodge and a block. They're both bad.
G) The interesting mechanics don't start until after you beat the first boss, and then it's: add range to an attack
H) You would think range would make the game playable. It doesn't. You need 5+ hits to kill 1 enemy, there's always 4 or more, and they attack faster than you, and you have a long recovery time. Also they can knock you on your butt.
I) There are random rabbits everywhere and if you hit one it turns into a powerful enemy. These rabbits intentionally jump through enemies trying to get you to hit them. This game literally wants to make your life unpleasant.

The Good:
A) The game does a good job of teaching you *some* of the mechanics. It expects you to figure out others on your own without any help.
B) The art is... okay I guess
C) I literally can't think of anything else. This game is terrible.

Should you buy it?

Buy this game for someone you don't like but don't want them to know you don't like them. It will make their life unpleasant and you can claim you didn't know it was that bad. But only do that if it's on sale, $20 USD is WAY too expensive for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099620752', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1692375597}
review: So, I tried to backtrack to finish a quest and then had to redo a boss battle because it triggered the event for a door closing while I actually exited. Okay, with the new spells, not that big a deal. Then, some stone blocks my path again though it should be gone. After I spend time farming stupid 300 rupees just porting back and forth smashing pots and lighting campfires. But those are just the smaller issues. The bigger issue is playing this on challenging and then realizing combat is mostly hit and run. The bosses were kinda fun I guess but when I considered whether I wanted to spend another 6-10 hours or whatever on this game or play something else instead, I just see no reason to play this. It's a shitty Zelda game really with some cool ideas that weren't implemented well. But I can totally see people enjoying this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198384351293', 'num_games_owned': 1187, 'num_reviews': 730, 'playtime_forever': 1161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1161, 'last_played': 1690844304}
review:
on the surface, this game looks average, but i absolutely loved it. 

it's a legend of zelda-style adventure with a cool custom combat system. you'll start off as a total weenie mage that cannot even fling a fireball, but you'll end up summoning a firestorm from hell by the endgame.

the story is passable and the lack of voice acting and animations are lame, but the spells and combat are well worth the price of admission. it's a small adventure that'll last 8-10 hrs, short and sweet. definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198780084706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1536219691}
review:
Played this years ago, feel felt like leaving a review today. It's a fun game, the art style is aesthetically pleasing and consistent, the puzzles are just challenging enough and there's quite a bit of variety in the spells you can make and use. There's not much replayability but at least one playthrough should be fun. I spent ~13h on my first playthrough.

Would recommend giving it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119601571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 686, 'last_played': 1689224779}
review: The game has some interesting mechanics to test around with for its magic system that can make it rewarding to dash around your enemies. But aside from achievements increasing the play time it doesn't have a complex enough combat system or rewarding enough story to make me feel satisfied after finishing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113850999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1688500904}
review:
I was waffling on how to rate this game, but in the end, no, I can't recommend it. There's potential here, certainly. The main gimmick, the spell crafting, is interesting, but there's some issues with the implementation that leave it far less enjoyable than it could be.

First, spells are either pathetically weak, or overly costly as you add modifiers and triggers to further spells to make them effective. Later in the game, it's easy to drain your mana in seconds, and then wait for the overly slow regen to top you back up. Additionally, the game is not the best at making it clear what some of the augments do, as some of them can have very different effects depending on if they're connected to the element or another augment. You can always test out the spells, but it's a bit tedious.

Second, combat. Wow, combat. I read some of the reviews and found people praising the combat and I honestly can't understand why. Single enemy encounters are fine, if a bit easy, and the bosses are usually pretty fun, provided they don't have adds. The biggest issue is projectile attacks. They're hard to read in the chaos, some of them have strong homing, and your guard is unidirectional and doesn't always work even when you block in the right direction. Toss several projectile enemies in one encounter, and you have a miserable experience.

On top of the issue with projectile enemies, there's the spell casting itself. Until you get the augment in the late midgame that speeds up casting (at the cost of higher mana consumption of course), spells take just a bit too long to come out. Worse, they have entirely too much recovery time, meaning if you want to block an incoming attack, you better hope you weren't attacking something yourself.

There are definitely some other positives to the game. The art is nice, sound design and music are decent. The story is simple and feels a bit rushed, but isn't awful. Some of the puzzles are pretty clever, although some of them are a pain, and about 10% of them have timers that are just a bit too strict to be fun.

I made it to the last area riding on those positives. However, the last area is a massive combat gauntlet, and it absolutely sucks. I was kind of middling on the game, but if it had ended with some more puzzles and a decent final boss, I could've recommended it, if only just barely. But that gauntlet? Tipped me well in the opposite direction. So no, I cannot recommend the game. I'd love to see what the developers could do in the future, as there's some good creativity here, but this title just isn't quite enough to pass muster.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050727530', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2962, 'last_played': 1686483994}
review: this game is adorable and plays very well. I love the spell system where you can create the spells you want and then makes you use them for some trials different ways to show you how they work. There are some combinations that are just brutal that will kill all the enemies quickly but that's much more complex than just a few runes and you mostly get them towards end game so you feel like a master mage. If you're look at this I say it's worth getting for the small story it has.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011172061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 735, 'last_played': 1685488913}
review:
It's a charming short game. I liked the mechanics and the story.
The story is the classic mages are persecuted because one mage went power hungry and almost destroyed the world and you happen to be born as a mage and when your powers awoke you accidentally burned down your home. Most of what happens is the standard you go around and help people and unlock your powers. Oh and you somehow ended up finding a suspicious talking spellbook.
While the story is cliche, what helped it is that the game is relatively short (10 hours 100%) so it doesn't feel like you played dozens of hours for poor payoff. I also liked that it teased a second game which I hope does get made.

The mechanics are refreshing and I like the idea of spellcrafting and augmenting your spells.
The one thing I would change is how clunky the controls feel at times. While most of the time it's fine? The aiming is really annoying when you're trying to complete a timed puzzle. Also there's a bug where if I try to shift tab to get into the steam overlay my character is stuck casting the spell bound to shift. If I do escape and then shift tab then when I go back to the game my character is stuck until I hit the shift key.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053957313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1138, 'last_played': 1682367069}
review: Any game that has magic should have some form of this games spell system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072094217', 'num_games_owned': 707, 'num_reviews': 617, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1682847274}
review: The controls feel sluggish and the character responds slow to my move inputs. Oh and it has that annoying blabbering games put in when they don't have money for voice acting. FFS people, just leave the text like that and don't add annoying sounds into the game instead of voice acting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098640215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1682770380}
review: Pretty fun game that is not too long and allows you to get pretty damned creative. Some of the puzzles can be pretty mind numbing to solve even when the game tells you what you need because you still have to put them in the right order and the right spell type. Shame this never got a sequel because it obviously set itself up for one and it never happened.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073415383', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1708135714}
review:
I was pretty upset of the disappointment that Borderlands 3 turned out to be. This game not only cheered me up it got me pretty interested and surprised of it's magic mechanics.

It's a game about a fuggly redhead who killed her family and burned her house when she sharted accidentally. I wish this game had a (non-woke) sequel, you don't see many unique games like this nowadays.

author: {'steamid': '76561198837929482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3130, 'last_played': 1682013481}
review: A very good game with a plethora of fun spells to craft

author: {'steamid': '76561198089273702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2427, 'last_played': 1681714298}
review: This is, (and will be for a good  time), the best magic game you can find.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033798586', 'num_games_owned': 1543, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1681659411}
review:
This was a joy to play.  
A short (10 hr) adventure that was quite creative, due to how spells are so customizable I doubt two people will end up with the same arsenal.

Definitly eager to hear news of a sequel!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035182410', 'num_games_owned': 1144, 'num_reviews': 372, 'playtime_forever': 542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1681140002}
review:
The puzzles are like in Trine: sure there is an intended solution. But you can also just spam fireballs until you randomly unlock the chest. 

The magic crafting system is interesting but since most interactions are hidden, somewhat annoying to figure out. For instance: "duplicate" on earthspell transforms the shield into a statue. Yeah that's obvious, isn't it? 

Otherwise kind ok mindless brawler type game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996694272', 'num_games_owned': 841, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1493880847}
review: A charming gem of a game where you travel a land crafting spells to defeat enemies and solve puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999704027', 'num_games_owned': 2072, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1678845791}
review:
Mages of Mystralia has an amazingly interesting and creative magic system that's very similar to that of Obsidian's Tyrrany.  My biggest disappointment with the game was that the best parts of customizing your spells comes so close to the end of the game.
Early game feels rather slow, and combat was lacking until unlocking more spells and runes.  But once that happens it really starts to shine.  The game sets up the story for a sequel, which as far as I can tell has no news as the development team has been silent since 2019, which is a bit sad.  I would have loved to see what else they would do in this world, and in a sequel expanding on these systems with even more polish.
Despite this, the game is absolutely worth playing and is easily 100%-able for achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561199180909038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1692874986}
review: Short but extremely sweet game. The spellcrafting is amazing, and the endgame-level spells you can make are blissfully op. Highly recommend to anyone interested in magic gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039416673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1624, 'last_played': 1595693473}
review:
I really like this game. The game mechanics are well thought out and the story is very interesting.
Would definitely recomment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155451029', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1298, 'last_played': 1667011400}
review:
By the time I got to the [spoiler] village burning down [/spoiler] I was bored and done with the game.

Huge spellcrafting system with nothing to use it on and nothing to use it for. Few actually useful or fun or necessary spells. I had moments when I fiddled with the spells, made something fun, then remembered that all I needed them for was to slaughter goblins, then decided that running was better. Dashing away while leaving a clone behind became my best spell. Suck it goblins! I have a game to finish.

Itâ€™s better to run from enemies than waste time fighting them. Combat is boring, time consuming and unrewarding.
You can get hit-stun-locked to death or you can just leave.
You can use ice spells to freeze the big goblins and the giant fat horned goblins, hit-stun-locking them to death, and unlike you they canâ€™t just leave. Aha! See how the tables have turned. Fun, funny, stupid, better just leave.

Very foreseeable story. â€œBan all magic! What could possibly go wrong?â€ â€œThe book?! Really?! No!â€ â€œThe councilor?! Really?! No!â€

Small world, small map, small lore. Feels like they live completely isolated from the world around them or there isnâ€™t even a world outside the valley at all.

The ending sets you up for a sequel . . . that will never happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198183195493', 'num_games_owned': 92, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1678065722}
review:
An really good 3D RPG style videogame with awesome gimmicks of creating your own spells while taking your journey through this world. 
The first hours into the game would be difficult but you will get the hang out of it, has some backtrack to get all the spells and upgrades, the medium difficulty is kinda hard so try easy mode if you want to enjoy the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108917366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1677989876}
review: It's a cute and fun little game. I tend to take everything really casually and dink around so it could easily be completed in less time then I have put in at the time of writing this. Had I cared I could have easily completed every achievement in that run but I had a little to much fun in the final tower! Totally worth the price even if it doesn't match up to my normal hours of play per $ desired ratio.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123996777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1026, 'last_played': 1676079615}
review: Underrated gem. Beautiful environments, beautiful music, very cool spellcrafting system. Story is pretty alright, game is a bit too short and side quests are dull, but none of these ruin the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999923780', 'num_games_owned': 427, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1397, 'last_played': 1663002381}
review:
Great little game! Not so little actually, it feels underrated.
No world-shattering ideas here, just a well-made, pleasant game, with fun gameplay (spell crafting) and a nice world to discover. Not easy but not overly challenging, perfect for kids!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068802723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1672002600}

author: {'steamid': '76561198138047622', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1671813753}
review: combat is dull and enemies take many hits while stunning you on every hit

author: {'steamid': '76561198043780861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1410, 'last_played': 1671743957}
review: The story is nice, battles are cool, whole game is enjoyable. The real treat among it all is the spellcrafting though. Every single spell you design is its own little puzzle, putting together the different pieces you have to see what you can make. Spells to blow stuff up, throw enemies around, freeze them then drop tons of rocks on them. Swarms of ever-multiplying fireballs that shoot lightning balls that shoot spikes from the ground that shoot... etc etc etc. It's wild and even after 100% completion, I've actually kept coming back once in a while, just to play with the spells and see what I could accomplish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198991259827', 'num_games_owned': 99, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1657657201}
review: One of the best games I've played. Truly amazing. Love the spellcrafting, art, battles and atmosphere of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071843594', 'num_games_owned': 182, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1671242930}
review:
This gets a thumbs up because there is no maybe. It's about a 6.5/10

The spell mechanic is excellent and would love to see it implemented in a better game.

The combat in this game is very flat. It's occasionally difficult but only because there's no depth to the combat beyond "hit enemy". The solution is to make enemies sponges and numerous. It's more frustrating than fun most of the time.

People really tried here, you can tell. I'll finish the game for the spell crafting. If the game didn't have spell making though, it'd be a 3/10 easy.

Get on sale, don't expect much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081413620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1669818204}

author: {'steamid': '76561199229588883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1008, 'last_played': 1669578222}
review:
I love the game. A kind of Legend of Zelda, with some extra exciting spell crafting. The mix of runes and their effects are good enough to keep you entertained. Added to that, the maps are fantastic, the story is kind of cliched but still works, and there is some boldness that is refreshing.
Totally recommend it, and looking forward to a continuation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998598944', 'num_games_owned': 2059, 'num_reviews': 1152, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1669068106}
review:
I really like the idea of this game, but I feel like it was half baked.  The level and bosses were pretty standard-fare, but the reason you even consider this game is the spell-creation mechanic.  The issue with this is the spells you can create are not infinite or even come across as being deep.  There's really only a handful of spells worth-a-damn, so you are left with a so-so game and a game mechanic that leaves you wanting for more.

It's not a terrible game, but there's many better options out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018180776', 'num_games_owned': 1192, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1120, 'last_played': 1668462028}
review: Short but sweet game. Spell crafting is by far and away the big appeal. If you have ANY interest in being to make your own doom weapon, you owe it to yourself to try this at some point. Biggest problem with the game is how short it is and if that's all I can come up with then it's worth a play on sale at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061446983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1051, 'last_played': 1664069083}
review:
This gets a solid "meh" from me.

Unfortunately, Steam does not (yet) allow that rating, so I had to struggle a bit about whether to round up or round down. Â Obviously I rounded up. Â Mostly because I want to see more of these types of games made in the future.

The spell crafting system is genius! Â I love it so much!!Â  But there are a lot of aspects that seem to matter a lot and are never explained at all (most notably stuff along the lines of the difference between a duplicate --> size rune placement and a size --> duplicate rune placement).

There is a lot of stuff to do in this game that really requires a guide to do it.Â  Finding the ghosts, finding Anna or looking under that bridge just to name a few off the top of my head (there are many, many more).Â  I think I'm safe in saying that you can get through the main game on your own, but if you want to 100% it then you'll definitely need to refer to a guide (or put in hundreds of hours - maybe even thousands) to figure out some of the stuff.Â  That's a big point against for me.

And it would be really nice if the puzzle editor had some extra features.Â  Like being able to lock in a piece as "I'm sure this must go here" and making it visually obvious to ourselves that ... instead of rambling I'm just gonna say it: pencil marks in Sudoku.Â  There were two puzzles in the game where I had to retreat after copying down all the info into a different format and then come back with a solution because that formatting did so much more to let me get there.

I enjoyed this game a lot!!Â  The storyline is quite amazing for a lot of reasons (though a lot of plot holes are left open, hopefully obviously for an expansion pack).Â  I'm a really big fan of the idea of it not being about what you are using - that it's much more about why and how you are using it.Â  This game's plot dips a foot, probably even an ankle and a knee into that water (jumping in is one of those plot holes).

I focus more on the negatives because those are things that can (and should) be fixed.Â  But I had a lot of fun playing this game.Â  And I think you would, too.

But, to end on a general note to all games: please never again do the thing where you expect us to wait through a credits scroll after we finish the game.Â  That makes sense for a movie in a movie theatre, but definitely not for a game.Â  Put an option on the main menu to view the entire credits scroll at any time for any reason and leave it at that.Â  Please.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029859649', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1663005354}
review: Hidden gem!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003709109', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1662304898}
review: Great puzzle based arpg about a trainee mage that is learning how to use her spells whilst trying to save her village. This game is pretty unique; you collect runes in order to create your own elemental spells - there are lots of different combinations to try. Create these spells to take down enemies and solve puzzles, whilst working your way through the story and finding treasures along the way. Collect all the runes, wands and orbs, and have fun trying to make super powerful spells to wipe out your enemies. Mages of Mystralia feels really fresh, with a cute style to boot. A lovely game for a mixture of puzzles, action and unique gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971100483', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1662293601}
review: This is a great little 3d adventure game. The cool thing is, that you have four basic spells that you can build/modify with lots of options. The puzzles are very nice. Often you need to modify your spells to solve them. The fights aren't too easy but not too hard either. The bosses are funny. The game is a little on the short side, but on the other hand they don't overstay their welcome. Do recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198176643635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1666089222}
review: Very fun and intriguing. The spell customization system is very maleable and rewards of creativity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022517753', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1661804073}
review:
A nice and refreshing adventure game, full of magic and exploration.

You can combine and create spells; mix and match, springing one spell off from another. You need that ability to craft new combat options, traversal methods, and solve uniquely designed puzzles.

By the end I had a spells that melted baddies with raining fire or just basically deleting the entire room with self replicating spells (and most of my mana bar) but I still was having fun and went for 100% completion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971880699', 'num_games_owned': 2849, 'num_reviews': 419, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1661338264}
review:
Duration: 8 hours.

Genre: 2D fantasy Action Adventure

A fairly straight-forward explore, collect stuff, solve optional challenge rooms etc style of game.  A decent play.  Combining elements to create cool spells adds something unique, but limited mana really stops one from having destructive fun with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968231044', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1096, 'last_played': 1661053713}
review: There is a software, Citrix, or something along that name, which, if installed on your pc, will prevent you from being able to launch this amazing game. The combat, puzzles, lore, and characters are to die for. 10/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198016655090', 'num_games_owned': 764, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1674316817}
review: Super fun I love the magic system it's a puzzle with hundreds of solutions and while the story can seem simple that's not really a bad thing

review: Fun spell system, but everything else is kind of mediocre.  Still worth a playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007796302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1658893324}
review:
Story was great, world and story were engaging, combat and spellcrafting were fun (despite, or maybe because of, the frustration of mastering the system).

I just finished it, and I'm already hungry for a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056365904', 'num_games_owned': 598, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 815, 'last_played': 1656018907}
review: Mages of mystralia is a charming and easy going game about becoming a magic user in a world nearly devoid of magic users due to previous events in the world's history. I'll admit I was interested in the spell crafting as that was one of the big selling points for the game and although it certainly was a bit slow to start, about less than halfway through the game I had a recursive casting barrage of fire that any arch-mage would be proud of. This game is full of fairly easy puzzles, zelda-like exploration, and a simple yet effective story to help you keep going. I'd confidently suggest this little gem of a game for those who are interested in such types of games and even for those who just want to mess around to see what kind of carnage they can create with the crafting system. Just to be clear although it's "crafting" spells it doesn't actually cost anything to play around with the components so it's more like spell shaping!

author: {'steamid': '76561198219560909', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1587008189}
review:
I first tried the game at the Montreal Comiccon, I don't remember the year though.
I was happy to play it again when it came out in 2017, the game may be short but it is fun, has great puzzles and mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037648448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1654481060}
review:
Extremely linear progression, forgettable story is a chore. The spell design system is neat but it just isn't enough to redeem the rest of the game, particularly when you need to get more than an hour or so in to actually get enough runes to create novel spell combinations.

Until then, the game does nothing to respect your intelligence. It just sorta gives you a stationary torch spell. Eventually it gives you a 'forward' rune like "look, you can shoot fireballs now! Don't hurt yourself, better take it slow."

No one interested in the spellcrafting system of this game will enjoy the story progression of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026651982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1653750880}
review:
A tad bit more difficult than expected but an idie gem.
Gameplay is akin to 2D Zelda games like Link to the Past or Links Awakening but with magic as only combat option. The spell crafting system is unique and very enjoyable but only takes place a good hour into the story. Before that you need to play with the lackluster base spells. A few hours in the game the spell crafting becomes very intersing since you unlock new modifiers to "programm" your own spells.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963094949', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1653417495}
review: A great, fun little game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103420866', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1652686287}
review:
The spell-crafting system feels fun to mess around, but it felt held back by the mana economy.

This was extremely apparent when you create and use advanced spells (spells that activate other spells). When the triggered spell activates, mana is expended at that point in time. It starts to make using your EGO (shield/dodge) really difficult in battle.

Now this may be caused by my advanced spell having unnecessary runes, but designing spells is a core aspect of the game. It felt restrictive, but Mages of Mystralia is worth a playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198315237893', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 1191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1191, 'last_played': 1613850981}
review:
[i]Review originally on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/christmas-steam-games-2020-quickmehs/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

This is a game where you play as an apprentice mage who must fight monsters to save the world from evil. The main selling point of the game is that you construct your own spells out of basic functions to fight enemies and solve puzzles. For example, the initial â€œfireballâ€ spell is just a stationary mine, but by adding a â€œmoveâ€ rune, you can make it a flying fireball. From there, you can add a â€œhomingâ€ rune to make it seek out enemies, and a â€œduplicationâ€ rune to fire a spread shot of three fireballs at once. You can even chain multiple spells together using conditionals, such as executing a powerful short-range spell when your ranged missile hits an object.

The game is also hard as nails. Even routine encounters will see you swarmed with monsters who all have immense durability. I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m just making bad spells, but even when I try to spec for AoE I frequently get overwhelmed. Checkpoints are pretty sparse, so itâ€™s very easy to lose progress when an encounter suddenly goes south. I found it more frustrating than challenging, and I recommend playing on easy mode.

The spell-crafting mechanic is neat, but quite backloaded. The game gives you new runes only at a trickle, and many of them are locked behind difficult puzzles and optional challenges. Unfortunately, a lot of the runes had no real use outside of puzzles â€” itâ€™s pretty easy to make some effective combat spells with the early runes, and later runes donâ€™t provide much practical improvement. You can do fancy stuff like making your clones spit fireballs, but why would you when direct damage is so much more efficient? I would have liked to see the â€œpuzzleâ€ aspect extend more to enemies, with more variety in enemy behavior beyond just â€œresists a different elementâ€. You can get through most of the game with a nested-function spell that cycles through all elements without really having to bother with anything else.

Plotwise, the game perpetuates the worst messages about oppression and authoritarianism. Mages used to rule the world, but one of them went mad with power, so the people rebelled, killed him, and outlawed mages. The problem is that magic is an innate trait, so we end up with a Dragon Age situation where people are illegal just for existing. The game opens with the protagonist getting chased from her village after accidentally burning down her cottage, at which point an old mage pops up out of nowhere, condescends to her a bunch, and declares that heâ€™s training her now. Shockingly, he isnâ€™t evil; the game apparently does not expect us to find anything suspicious about this. The protagonist is somehow capable of returning to her hometown without issue as long as she doesnâ€™t use magic, at which point everyone microaggresses her about how terrible mages are but they guess that sheâ€™s one of the good ones. But this supposed intense hostility to mages never does more than inconvenience the protagonist, and she never stands up for herself. Itâ€™s a totally bizarre depiction of oppression completely removed from any real-world problems.

Oh, also you murder goblins by the hundreds, even after learning that theyâ€™re sapient and some talk to you. But the game makes a point of showing that you only knock out the human magefinders sent to hunt you down, because murder is wrong when you do it to humans.

Furthermore, the ending is a complete non-resolution sequel hook. Like, literally, it sets up what looks like the final boss and then it just ends. Stop selling incomplete products, gamedevs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095697115', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1648936019}
review:
It's alright, but lacks some essence. I loved level design and metroidvania-style are layouts. Environment art style is very elegant. Snappy, responsive controls contribute to a very smooth experience. But mechanically this game does not offer much.

The spell-designing gameplay gimmick is unique and has the potential to be a lot of fun, but it's greatly underutilized. According to the in-game counter, I've completed ~60% of the game, and ~50% available runes, and I still can't make more than ~10 different spell combinations that are actually useful. Puzzles are not just easy, but very uninspired, relying on tricks that are popular in the platform game genre, rather than making clever use of spell combinations.

And despite being marketed as such, this is not really a puzzle game; a vast vast majority of the time is spent fighting endless hordes of enemies respawning whenever you return to an area. Even on the easy ("adventure-focuses") difficulty these fights are very difficult, and boss fights are particularly challenging, even using clever and powerful spell combinations. Maybe this grind is a way to disguise that there isn't that much content in the game, according to the progress meter, I would have completed it in ~10 hours.

But I gave up as the constant combat was tiring and too boring. It's particularly frustrating considering the very sparse distribution of save points (no manual saves!) in some regions, forcing me to replay large areas just because I kept falling of a platform in a time-sensitive puzzle. That's just too annoying.

I also felt that the game punishes me for exploring too much. Which is very weird given the multi-hub design on the world. The game expects you to follow to the destination by the most logical path, many other ways get blocked for no good reason whatsoever, and fast-travel point locations were picked specifically to never be useful. Which, again, forces you to engage in more combat.

Completely forgettable and bland story doesn't give any extra motivation to keep playing, and neither does the very basic character design.

I realized I had more fun anticipating how game mechanics will evolve as I progress further, than actually playing with these mechanics. Which only proves the idea's great and has huge potential, but it's not fully utilized.

author: {'steamid': '76561198388469738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1181, 'last_played': 1630735403}
review: Probably one of my favourite quickish games, spammed it in a couple of days! Similar mechanics to Magika 2, but wayyyy more creative. Puzzle-solving is quite easy, maybe a handful of challenging ones but not impossible. You can do so many combinations of spells (spellcrafting). It has good soundtrack, not much NPC interaction and a simple story. The gameplay was probably more the focus. Would recommend (:

author: {'steamid': '76561198040037265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 469, 'playtime_forever': 1106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1646008279}
review:
[code]Puedes ver mÃ¡s reseÃ±as como esta en la mentorÃ­a [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Realmente Ãºnico[/h1]
Mages of Mystralia ofrece una historia de un reino que ha sufrido una Ã©poca oscura debido a la locura de un mago que llegÃ³ al poder y que sumiÃ³ al mismo en la oscuridad. DespuÃ©s de ser derrotado, los magos se convirtieron en proscritos y nuestra protagonista un dÃ­a se da cuenta de que tiene poderes mÃ¡gicos que no puede controlar. Algo que descubre al quemar una casa del pueblo donde vivÃ­a. AsÃ­ que decide huir y ahÃ­ comienza nuestra aventura.

Cuando en su dÃ­a supe que el creador de los Reinos Olvidados de Dungeons & Dragons iba a ser el padre de la historia de Mages of Mystralia, pensÃ© que probablemente serÃ­a algo realmente magnÃ­fico e irrepetible. 

Lo cierto es que despuÃ©s de haber acabado Mages of Mystralia he de reconocer que la historia es lo menos bueno del juego. Para ser claro, la historia es ramplona, simple y para nada memorable. No es que sea mala, pero es que no destaca en nada de cualquier otra historia que se haya visto antes.

Y es que Mages of Mystralia no es un juego que destaque por casi nada dentro de la plÃ©tora de juegos que llegan al mercado en un aÃ±o cualquiera. Pero el â€œcasiâ€ es importante. Este juego tiene, sin duda, el mejor sistema de magias que vas a poder ver en un juego.

El sistema funciona mediante runas que vamos encontrando durante el juego, algunas nos las darÃ¡n mientras avanzamos y podremos realizar los hechizos mÃ¡s bÃ¡sicos, como tirar bolas de fuego, crear remolinos de viento, lanzar rayos o crear suelos de hielo para superar determinados terrenos. Luego hay otras runas que las obtendremos si las buscamos, realizamos diferentes puzles y al terminar misiones secundarias.

La gracia del asunto es que no nos dicen cÃ³mo crear tal o cual hechizo, y es ahÃ­ donde nos pondremos a investigar colocando las runas en nuestro libro de hechizos para ver si sucede algo o no.

Por poner un ejemplo, supongamos que descubrimos una runa que hace llover, y entonces pensamos que tal vez serÃ­a una buena idea mezclar esa runa con el elemento del trueno y al hacerlo descubrimos que hemos creado un hechizo para que llueva y a la vez realice descargas elÃ©ctricas sobre los enemigos. Y luego, vamos mÃ¡s allÃ¡ y pensamos en mezclar la lluvia con el hechizo de fuego y nos sorprendemos al ver que hemos creado un hechizo de ataque que hace llover fuego sobre los enemigos. Es realmente casi ilimitable las posibilidades que ofrece este sistema.

De hecho, se pueden crear hechizos realmente espectaculares, muy poderosos y todo ello a partir de nuestra propia imaginaciÃ³n y ganas de investigar. Sin duda esto es lo mejor del juego con diferencia.

Puedes aÃ±adir hechizos de rayo, con los de fuego y piedra y despuÃ©s usar una runa de volumen para que caiga un peÃ±asco sobre los enemigos para terminar de redondear nuestra obra maestra reciÃ©n creada, pero eso sÃ­, tampoco podemos aÃ±adir todo lo que queramos porque cada hechizo consume manÃ¡, y mientras mÃ¡s efectos acumulamos en un solo hechizo, asÃ­ lo harÃ¡ el gasto del mismo y puede pasar que creemos algo muy poderoso, pero de muy poca duraciÃ³n, por lo que se volverÃ¡ inÃºtil en combate.

Es toda una gozada ir investigando por los bosques y aplicar la magia que personalmente hayamos creado y ver como el enemigo cae a nuestros pies vÃ­ctimas de nuestro poder, e imaginaciÃ³n, como magos. Como he comentado antes, es un sistema realmente Ãºnico en un videojuego.

Sin embargo, el resto de la aventura es simplemente pasable. Es decir, no estÃ¡ mal como tal, pero tampoco es nada memorable. Ni su historia, ni sus personajes, ni sus enemigos, ni los jefes finales, ni las misiones secundarias, ni el lore, ni nada parecido.

Es un juego agradable, aunque no casual porque puede llegar a ser bastante difÃ­cil en los niveles normal y difÃ­cil, que se disfruta mÃ¡s que nada por el asunto de la preparaciÃ³n de hechizos y su aplicaciÃ³n prÃ¡ctica en la aventura.

Seguro que has jugado mÃ¡s de un juego donde llevas a un mago y vas aprendiendo hechizos mientras mÃ¡s avanzas por la aventura. En este caso esto no es asÃ­, ya que mientras mÃ¡s avanzas por la misma conseguirÃ¡s mÃ¡s runas, pero eres tÃº quien tiene que configurar esas runas para poder crear algo realmente poderoso. Puede parecer algo molesto, pero una vez que se entiende el sistema y aprendes a combinarlas, la experiencia es realmente genial.

De todos modos, si el combinar runas no es lo tuyo y prefieres que te lo den todo mascado, el juego se preocupa de enseÃ±arte los hechizos mÃ¡s bÃ¡sicos con los que podrÃ¡s pasar la aventura sin ningÃºn problema. No serÃ¡ tan espectacular ni divertido, pero podrÃ¡s hacerlo.

Como tal, el juego no es rol, es mÃ¡s un juego de acciÃ³n y aventura donde la magia juega un papel fundamental en el desarrollo de la historia. 

Tengo muy claro que sin el aÃ±adido tan espectacular del uso de la magia este juego no serÃ­a nada del otro mundo, pero la cuestiÃ³n es que sÃ­ lo hace, y crea algo muy diferente a la hora de enfocar algo tan sumamente trillado como la magia y los magos en un videojuego, y eso es muy de agradecer.

AsÃ­ que ya sabes, si quieres disfrutar de una aventura entretenida con un sistema de hechizos totalmente diferente a lo ya visto tanto por su originalidad como por las posibilidades casi ilimitadas que ofrece no puedes perderte Mages of Mystralia. La historia y su lore las olvidarÃ¡s en poco tiempo, pero su sistema de magia es algo que recordarÃ¡s para siempre. De eso puedes estar seguro.

review: I would give this game a 6 out of 10.  It was fun, decent story, cool spell system, but it just didn't have a lot of depth.  I mostly felt like there was a lot of potential.  One glaring problem was no health potions or way of healing yourself before fights other then go around and bang open jars, it was just easier to die and start with full life.  Definitely only buy on sale as there just isn't a lot of depth to this game, maybe the part 2 will be better as it ended with the story not concluded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076888592', 'num_games_owned': 658, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1643326318}
review: It's a cute "Legend of Zelda" type game with a key mechanic being the spell creation mechanic. I don't think it's a very complex spell building game; you're just adding bells and whistles to your existing spells for the most part. Combat is incredibly basic. Without doing all the side bits I imagine the game takes only about 10-15 hours. Optional puzzles are probably the hardest part of the whole game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198408549319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1644340872}
review:
The concept of spellcraft in this game is seemingly interesting, but it gets tedious soon as you realize that you are doing repetitive things over and over again. I was expecting the sort of magic combination like the Invoker in Dota2 or something like that, but I was wrong. The spellcraft in the game, to be precisely, doesn't create much new magic. You collect runes to ALTER the basic spells, to add some extra functions to them, etc. But the core function of the spell is fixed. For example, a ranged attack spell of fireball is still a fireball spell. It's not gonna become a firestorm spell or something totally different, it is a fireball and always it will be. And I'm not saying there's not any spell that adds something different, there are but very few so that I consider it to be none. So, precisely, it's about combining rather than creating. No need to mention that many runes are useless and they are not fun either. For example, there is a rune called right (your spell will be casted in the direction of right), and seriously, what's the meaning of it? Why would I need a spell like this? Looking for trouble? I could simply change my direction and cast a spell. But if you love geometry, just ignore what I said. Well, many runes are useless, or useful only in specific occasions, but most importantly, they are not fun at all. It seems like you've got the freedom to combine as you wish, but you have to get the runes first, and you get the runes only as the story line goes, and most of the time you use the runes to combine into new spells only to do specific things, cuz honestly, several spells would be enough for completing the whole game. So it feels like being controlled by the game, the game wants me to craft this spell, the game wants to craft that spell, and I have no idea what kind of spell I really want cuz THERE IS NONE.
  But these are just my personal opinions. The game is not that bad, but not good either. 
  Not worth playing for the whole price. But can have a try on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990572324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1644202677}
review: This game is needlessly tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156591760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1200, 'last_played': 1644200396}
review: I was looking for casual games for the during times and I came upon this little gem. I could see why people don't like it, but if you are looking for something to just chill with on a weekend this is perfect. I really like the way that spells are crafted and making new ones based on how you organize the aspects of them. And the general puzzle solving to progress the story. I also found the world fun to get around and the boss battles challenging but not frustrating. This game is not trying to break the mold or anything it's just a fun little game about being a girl with powers she doesn't quite understand.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245291730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 856, 'last_played': 1644214239}
review: El spellcrafting de este juego es de otro nivel, brutal. La calidad de jugabilidad, banda sonora y de arte tambiÃ©n son muy buenos.

author: {'steamid': '76561199160860987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1644275191}
review:
Once you get used to what the game is expecting of you and how to align your spells as you go, it is definitely entertaining! I strongly recommend using a controller though (the game even recommends doing so). The controls on a controller are a lot easier to use rather than using the keyboard and mouse.

Update:
I didn't think I would finish the game so quickly >.> so I do wish there was more to the story or even a sequel. Overall though, it was still enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198309372748', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1644006303}
review:
didnt like this one.
story is the usual fantasy nonsense with you being a powerful mage bossed around like a lowly servant by every peasant you meet.
controls arent tight so you have to take delays into account so fights feel clumsy, not satisfying enough.
bought the game for magic system, but it feels there's just predefined set of spells, that correspond to certain combinations of runes, with rune meaning changing unpredictably.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107380407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 833, 'last_played': 1643657118}
review:
This game is... fine. The spellcraft system is interesting and innovative (like Magicka, but different), but the story and overall gameplay is boring and not challenging at all. There is no reason to play the hardest difficulties either.
Maybe in a sequel?

author: {'steamid': '76561197970525844', 'num_games_owned': 1540, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1643681562}
review: This is an excellent game - the vibe is super nice and wholesome, the puzzles are fun, but the magic system is exceptional - it allows for a huge range of creativity in puzzle solving and combat,  and is the ultimate game in this regard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072253081', 'num_games_owned': 767, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1643654220}
review:
This game has some bugs, graphical flickering (most noticeable with ice spells) and bad enemy AI. I get that goblins may not be bright, but running perfect circles and not engaging, or not being able to path around fences and across bridges looks bad.
The unresponsiveness of spells and inability to interrupt animations makes combat on medium or harder difficulty a frustration, as seen when casting a fireball and not being able to block afterward. This unresponsiveness also makes puzzles a frustration which require casting spells in quick succession.
All in all, this game is not worth investing your time.  
For some reason this bish can [spoiler] swim in the first cutscene where the bridge blows out [/spoiler], but water kills you everywhere else in the game.  Smart.
Another Humble Bundled game that was free on Epic.  Good riddance to HB.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996964927', 'num_games_owned': 874, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1642878463}
review: It's said that trying to overcome every obstacle with the just one idea is "when all you have is a hammer, every problem looks like a nail." Mages of Mystralia gives you an industrial warehouse of tools you can mix together, but most of the time all you need to do is figuratively put the nail in a board. There are four spell types, four elements, and 23 spell modifier runes you can get in the game (some acquired during the story, many optional), but even during the last dungeon you'll still mostly just chuck fireballs at enemies and occasionally use a platform-creation spell. Each of the preceding areas has one new trick you need to use to solve its puzzles, but then afterwards they're mostly pointless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060910104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1642539953}
review:
Great game.
The spellbook system is great.
You can be very creative in the crafting of the spells.
Even after completing the story, you will want to come back and try all the different spell possibility.
First, because they are endless and second because the story is pretty short.

I do hope for a sequel in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034244487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1642027367}
review:
Great game. I 100% it in 12 hours, so that's what it can offer imo.

Plays like a mix of a Zelda game with Magicka. The spell system is very unique and creative, I've not seen another game allow for this type of mechanic and it was great to play around with! 

Solid recommendation, it is very good!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993589165', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1621888519}
review:
Sadly enough, I canâ€™t really recommend this game. Yes, like everybody said (or so), the spell mechanic is innovative and quite interesting, but at the same time, it is complex for no reason and some "spells" should just be basic skills, not spells (like dashing for instance).  Graphics are OK, without being anything impressive, the sound is OK too.

The problem is, the story, the feeling and more importantly the gameplayâ€¦ itâ€™s pretty boring to be honest. Iâ€™ve done Hob in one go, and I would rather play it again or redo one of the Zelda games rather than play more of this one. The game is feeling correct at the start, but it's one of those games where after a while, you are like... why I should waste my life on this. The game just don't give you the trill or interest to keep going.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117399468', 'num_games_owned': 1031, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1638550386}
review:
A perfectly acceptable game, but not... good. 

-- Character dialogue is absolutely not engaging. I found no investment in the characters of the world.

-- The game is incredibly easy and, to an extent, tedious.

-- Movement is slow, with little engaging content between point A and point B. 

++ The magic building system is interesting, but its presence in an uninteresting game isn't enough to save it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093827298', 'num_games_owned': 871, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1637600885}
review:
hate it, made me rage quit with the normal difficulty not being able to take out the large groups of enemies that have a huge health pools for each one, and i believe the 2nd boss is what made me rage the most as it locked me in a damage loop of getting pushed off the level 3 times and taking the hit before being pushed off again since it was still doing its animation. not only is the game unforgiving it is down right dirty with its mechanics.

puzzle ideas and item collectibles are good and the magic system behind the attacks building is interesting but the way they start you off is rough

may come back to it when im not salty with how the boss did me wrong

author: {'steamid': '76561198053224702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1463, 'last_played': 1637496959}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030388002', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1636755467}
review:
The game is a splendid journey from start to finish, with a charming art style and few but deep systems.
At the core of the game is the modular magic system around which most of your progress is centered. Each layer added throughout the game gives tou more to play with and more areas to access.

Overall if you are looking for a good short game to immerse yourself in that can be surprisingly challenging at times then this game is the one for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043642717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1635365929}
review:
Achievements: There are no missable achievements. All achievements can be obtained on any difficulty.  There is one speed run achievement for a specific dungeon of the game, but it is not unreasonable and can be reattempted.  

Mages of Mystralia is a spell crafting game with Zelda-like dungeons and puzzles.  Spells each have different elements and are used for both combat and puzzles, so there's plenty of excuses to tweak them.  There's also a ton of spell components that can hugely diversify the possible spells you can make.  Spells can even be recursive-- recasting themselves infinitely until your mana is depleted.  It's a fun system to mess around with.  

Be aware that I played this game on normal-- the easiest of the three difficulties.  I died once for an achievement, but otherwise never really struggled.  It was a bit of a cakewalk, not unenjoyable though-- and it also made the achievements easier to obtain.  The other difficulty selection (other than permadeath mode) had much harder combat that I was not patient enough to deal with.  Unfortunately, that difficulty also had more challenging puzzles that I would've loved to experience.  Not only is it disappointing to have essentially two difficulty settings ranging from easy to insane, it also sucks to have no separate settings for puzzles/combat and no way to change difficulty midway through.  

Another issue I had was with the game's UI.  The spell crafting menu felt really clunky.  I played with a controller-- as the game recommends-- but the crafting screen felt unintuitive to navigate with a joystick.  Also, there's a map, but it only really shows where areas connect.  A smaller map for each area would've helped out a lot, since many areas were fairly non-linear with branching paths for secrets and optional challenges.  

I had a lot of fun with Mages of Mystralia.  It gave me that wonderfully nostalgic Zelda feeling with its dungeons, each introducing some unique power that was crucial for the dungeon's puzzles.  While I was disappointed with the choices of difficulty as well as some UI clunkiness, my overall experience with the game was largely positive.  It was satisfying to find better spell components after feeling so powerless as a fledgling mage.  It's a little short, but I imagine it would've lasted longer if I was playing on a harder difficulty.  If you're interested, I'd recommend it.

review: Muy lindo juego, tanto en lo visual como en lo musical. El poder customizar los hechizos le da un vuelta de tuerca a las mecÃ¡nicas del juego, y los puzzle son ingeniosos. Lo recomiendo y espero la segunda parte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049686767', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1649649716}
review:
It's similar to zelda games: puzzles that have to be solved after the aquisition of some item (except in this case it's spell components), some combat, not much of a story. The isometric view can occasionally mess with you. The combination of spells that can be done makes the game quite enjoyable. 

Definitely recommend.

The graphics seemed simple at the beginning but grew on me :)

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198025061840', 'num_games_owned': 725, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1631474246}
review:
Almost a good game.

Targeting can be frustratingly clunky for a game that throws so many enemies at you at once. The wind-down on animations makes combat especially frustrating, as you often have 4+ ranged enemies throwing projectiles at you, but attack animations are so long that you don't have time to dash/shield.

Spellcrafting system is interesting, but you just end up using the same 4 basic abilities most of the time and swapping out to a special spell every now and then for a puzzle.

Enemies that you've already killed coming back when you re-enter an area is just exhausting. Doubly so since the "difficulty" of the game comes from throwing huge groups at you rather than interesting challenges.

author: {'steamid': '76561198888091805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1178, 'last_played': 1630824446}
review: Toda una experiencia. Es un juego que se nota esta hecho con amor. Es cierto que hay algunas cosas que pudieron haberse pulido mas, sin embargo se entiende dado el estatus indie del juego. Totalmente recomendado para aquellos que han disfrutado juegos al estilo The legend of zelda.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996081232', 'num_games_owned': 504, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1630717707}
review:
Ridiculously unbalanced (at least on archmage (hard) difficulty).
The game will throw unreasonable amount of enemies at you at once (7 and more), ideally each one with different element resistance (immunity). Some of them will throw a nearly unavoidable projectiles at you (some follow you around, some just have secondary action on impact), some of them will multiple on death and/or revive after short unless final blow is dealt while more of enemies are still spawning. Some of them will stun you and if you manage to free yourself, you're immediately stunned again and the rest of enemies will simply club you to death in single second.
Every defense or attack requires mana which with this amount of enemies is gone in instant and then you have to run around like madmad waiting for it to recharge while trying to avoid all the enemies and projectiles. If you're lucky, you kill two enemies before your mana runs out. Plus you can't even cast spells while walking so you have to stop, turn around and cast the spell, leaving you much more vulnerable. And the dash move to get away is also a spell and requires mana.
And the checkpoint system is infuriating. Checkpoints are pretty much only on border of each map so if you die during some of the challenges which are in the middle of the map, you have to fight your way over there again and again. Luckily the bosses are relatively close to the checkpoints but it still takes at least wasteful 30 seconds to get there and then you have to wait for unskippable boss introduction cutscene which plays every single time.

The story sounds interesting, but I'm not sure it's worth the trouble. Just play it at mage (normal) difficulty.
