author: {'steamid': '76561198107087793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1593465458}
review:
A very fun little adventure game with an engaging enough story and plenty of interesting puzzles and mini sidequests to do. I would like more from the puzzles and a little bit more complexity from the dungeons, but it was still a lot of fun to play through. Took me about ten hours to beat with lots of playing around, fighting mobs for fun and running in circles because I got a little lost. 

8/10 from me, would definitely reccomend

author: {'steamid': '76561198064910522', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1277, 'last_played': 1647707053}
review:
Pretty good game, with decent soundtrack, easy controls (a controller will really make your life easy and make the game fun).
There is kind of a plot line but it's not a story rich game.

The bosses can be challenging if you play on harder difficulties, so if you're looking for a challenge, then def play on medium or high difficulty, though the latter will be really tough.

There is some puzzling in the game to unlock some chests, but don't expect to do a lot of that. The spell crafting is unique in where you have to align runes together, but you can create A LOT of different spells.

You likely won't get like 40h of gameplay (I don't think you'd get there even if you 100% the game), but you can def get 20 hours on medium difficulty while still appreciating the game and atmosphere. But the playtime mostly depends on the difficulty since you will die more on higher difficulties.

You do run out of mana [b] very [/b] quickly, which can get annoying.

All in all, a very good indie game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992511533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1592697597}
review:
Terrible, clunky combat and an annoying user interface. Adjusting your spells can easily take over a minute, and in some fights needs to be done several times. Boss fights are just something else, long cycles of invulnerability coupled with lots of health, they are boring and drag on and on.

The spell system is sorta like Magicka or Eternal Darkness, but with an added aspect of having to align the runes so that they point at each other. This can force you to take a few minutes to shuffle things around correctly. This needs to be done EVER SINGLE TIME you want to adjust your spells.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025424829', 'num_games_owned': 1023, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1592585414}
review:
I want to like this game I really do. It's core mechanics and story are interesting and fun. Creating your own spells to solve puzzles and fight enemies is a really cool mechanic and I would say is one of the best elements of this game. (I've been playing through the game in Challenge Mode)

What ruins this game for me however is a combination of sloppy UI features, poorly thought out gameflow and the frustrating combat system.

The combat system is a great in principle. Custom spells and wands that power up certain elements is great!
BUT the enemies that have their attacks set to a cycle that is paired with your character's Stand up/unfreeze animation means that even 2 enemies can keep you in a cycle of getting knocked down over and over. A games combat system can be hard but preventing the player form moving makes the game feel noninteractive. 

Enemy hitboxes are another issue. Because the Dodge spell doesn't allow you to pass through enemies and the game often makes you fight many enemies in a small area your character can get caught in corners or between enemies. Which brings back the problem of stunlocks and the combat becoming noninteracive.

Both of these issues could be solved with a simple fix. If the dodge spell allowed you to pass through enemies (instead of colliding with them). A fluid dodge mechanic would make the tight fights a lot more fun.

And the stand up/take damage animation should not stop you from getting out of the way of further attacks! Make the enemies do more damage, make their attacks more frequent. But don't take away my ability to avoid them!

The second Issue was gameplay flow. Bosses repeating cutscenes EVERY time you try and face them is such a waste of player time. Having to go all the way back to Haven to get your mana potions back. The positioning of the teleport nodes making them completely useless 75% of the time. All leads to a boring and repetitive gameflow.

Finally and most Nitpicky! The UI design. 
- Interacting with all dialogue choices should allow you to use the controller buttons (A) and (B) to accept or decline the Hint/Sale/dialogue. 
- When purchasing Mana flowers there should be an option to purchase multiple at the same time! 
- There should be a way to choose which spells you have assigned to your quick select bar. I don't need all the spells I have built in there Just a few I want to quickly swap between in combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972318014', 'num_games_owned': 541, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1592171205}
review: While it is not great, there are no major flaws.  There were several annoyances throughout, but easily to avoid or move from and into another annoyance compounding the frustration.  This next part will sound strange, but want to avoid spoilers.  There were several areas of confusion the further I progressed into the game as well as parts of the game that were nice, but felt I did not need to learn until the game forced it upon me and so took that as a major no no.  I received this copy from a friend for free and while I do not regret playing it through its entirety (which is becoming harder for some games) I would feel ok with myself if I got this on a sale.  The spell designing is in short fantastic crap.  I really like what they came up with along with the combos that can be made, but the way to make them and how the components interact with each other is a mess.  Experimenting was great, but up to a point beyond basics as most of the time you are waiting for the mana to regenerate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076196468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1134, 'last_played': 1534393021}
review: This is a great game. Good puzzles, easy to learn, and lots of customisability with spells. Really good level design too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995212260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1590917707}
review: After beating game on hard I feel like I can leave a review on this one. The game is almost great but never fully realizes it's potential. It is a mix of puzzle/adventure game with a nice unique twist in the magic system. It is Zelda like in a lot of ways. There is not enough mob types or puzzles to really keep the game going so I was happy that I finished at about the 10-12 hour mark playing on the harder difficulty. The balance is off because toward the later parts of the game it got much easier as I unlocked more powerful spells and equipment, since you fight the same mobs all the time. I enjoyed the puzzle rooms and the boss fights the most, but there was not enough of either for my taste. I would give this game maybe a light recommendation to those who enjoy the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008466817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 819, 'last_played': 1590892236}
review: This is a nice short puzzle/action hybrid.  The puzzles can be a bit confusing because there are a really large way of combining runes, and some don't work even when you think they should.  Overall, though, a nice fun game.  I finished most in about 13 hours, but there were at least 1-2 more hours of stuff I probably missed.  If you like puzzle/action games, give this one a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134219338', 'num_games_owned': 1038, 'num_reviews': 768, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1590641684}
review: Definitely recommend this compact baby of Magika and Legend of Zelda. The combat felt very satisfying while still being simple, mainly by how easy it is to cycle between the complex spells you have prepared. My only two issues are that there are no area maps so I found myself frequently getting turned around and spending too long trying to figure out how to get out of or through areas, and also after any dialogue you must press A to proceed but then it immediately starts back up if you push it one too many times. Other than that Mages of Mystralia is a great game and the final boss fight actually took my full attention and effort which was necessary for some of the curve balls in the final fight.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967953654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1586525324}
review:
This is a neat beld of twin-stick shooter and Diablo-style exploration and questing. The advancement system has you getting pieces of spells which you can then combine together in different ways. I've only played one session so far so I don't know how far they take that concept, but at least the first few combinations that are opened up to you provide fun and flexibility. The controls also just feel good, which is nice!

Presentation and graphics are all neat, too. It's not the most technically advanced looking game in the world, but the visual design is all solid, and everything so far is nicely polished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259834141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1591693680}
review:
Is the game bad? No. But can I recommend it? No, & that kind of surprises me. I had high hopes for what is basically a l-o-n-g D&D campaign on the N64. There was a lot of work put into Mages of Mystralia & it shows, but I'm falling asleep after 30 minutes each time I boot it up. The plot is just so bland, under/overpowered & contrived that it takes away your agency as a player or easter eggs the keys to advancement. Maybe I'm not the target 8-15 year old audience here & maybe I'll change my mind if I finish the game; but at the rate I'm gong that's going to be in 40 boot-ups & I'd rather not waste my time after I've wasted my money.

TLDR=Killing an "evil tree" (AKA: A human killing tree) "Because I'm a mage & that's what mages do" isn't a plot or call to adventure, it's a chore forced upon you. You can't get invested into a game/story if there nothing interesting to invest into other than your guilt for being born with mana. Sure, The Witcher pulled that off. But Zia isn't a cowboy/mercenary with an elf-like lifespan killing hell horrors, shes a preteen-ish girl with a rating of E for Everyone against All Hallows' Eve cartoons. Basically shaming her into redemption via a life or death fight with a tree is just wrong is so many ways. The fight itself is fine, but if I fail or succeed it doesn't really matter. That "bad tree" won't go anywhere if I don't kill it, It'll just defend the forest(? Isn't that a good thing?) & the plot says it will grow back in 30 years anyway. Whatever I'm fighting for, (A trade road for a town that hates me?) doesn't seem worth it. If I just had options like (Neutral) to NOT help the town or (Evil) burn the town down in revenge (finish what I started /Moo-hahaa) then we could start a real story about what kind of mage (druid, warlock, shaman...) I'd become. 

"Crafting" spells is great, but the puzzles only have 1 answer, that means choice is not an option with this game. And if you don't realize that you can run on air with your [Dash] ability (since you don't use it or didn't think an EARTH ability lets you run on AIR), you're going to be stuck until you uninstall, then next month, you'll sneeze on your pop-tarts & realize the truth of why the game won't let you jump. Maybe I'm overthinking it, but I felt like I was sold on "You can do anything" & got "You're overpowered, until you have a rock in your way." Mage of Misty Australia you played yourself so well, it was a critical hit. You crippled yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090017284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1590549021}
review:
My thumb speaks for itself. Lengthy, rambly review ahead. Cut to the bottom for a succinct pro/con rating. Spoiler warning.

As one of my first and most beloved Steam purchases (please don't let my play hours deceive you) my feelings with Mages of Mystralia, now that I have completed the campaign, are mixed, but warm. This game straddles the line between the artistic Indie feel and the polished triple-A feel with poise and dignity, presenting itself with innocent charm. Its plot is simple enough that following it doesn't require a bulletin board spider web of strings and pushpins, while being complex enough to keep players here for the lore fully engaged. The graphics are simple, but pleasant and full of cartoonish charm without giving the art style over entirely to a goofy, irreverent aesthetic. The music is delightful and enchanting in every locale, though the recurring use of some leitmotifs will feel repetitive to some, it felt to me rather adhesive, useful to tie themes together. And all this before I've even come to the gameplay.

There is an entire webcomic devoted to Mages of Mystralia. I have not read it. So I cannot say, at this stage, whether it adds a great deal or is merely a pleasant prologue, setting the stage for the events to come in the game. But I can say most assuredly that the gameplay is the meat and potatoes of this game. When you play a tactical RPG like Shining Force, which I cut my teeth on in the early aughts, you expect the game to be 50-50 or better leaning on plot, pomp and presentation, with the half-or-less of the game's content being its tactical turn-based combat. I was delighted to find that the Banjo-Kazooie voiced dialogue and the simple but engaging cutscenes of MoM were plentiful but far from dominant in the game's presentation. Rather, the game throws you into a wide world, cut into rather definitively themed slices. These regions are populated with enemies diverse enough to keep you on your toes, but not so diverse that you're going to see a whole new cast of baddies with each region. The goblins, for instance, are palette-swapped between elemental resistances, but you're going to see them consistently from beginning to end; variety is leant more heavily to elemental strengths and weaknesses than to actual enemy design, which may be a problem in a 72-hour RPG, but less so in a 20-hour Zeldalike. And therein lie the game's key strengths.

MoM presents elemental magic as its sole medium of interaction with the world. If you want to attack something, you use magic. If you want to solve a puzzle, you use magic. If an enemy isn't dying quickly, you may be using your magic wrong. If a puzzle isn't making sense, you may not have the proper spell runes. Every step of the way, you will be using magic. And this is what drew me to the game in the first place: You design your own spells. Spell design is intuitive enough that you can brew a satisfying array of spells in a short amount of time, especially when using a keyboard and mouse to do so. It does present a challenge, though, by requiring you to discover runes to govern spell behavior on your own, and integrate them as you find them. [spoiler] Another such limitation is the locked-in elemental values of the four spell variants until halfway or so through the game, which was frustrating but gradually rewarding. [/spoiler] 

You can make a fireball that flies straight forward, or banks to the left or right, or homes in on enemies. Similarly, you can make any spell behave in any way you want so long as you've got runes for the behaviors you want the spell to perform. It doesn't take long to go from electric swipes of your wand to actual lightning storms, or rocky grenades that detonate with fiery force.

The dungeon design is extensive and delightful in its variety and the thought put into it. Each environment has new elements to interact with, and requires you to adapt to a new way of thinking to solve a new kind of puzzle. Similarly, the bosses--for the most part--will require carefully planned tactics and some particular spell use, though they offer enough freedom that it doesn't feel like the game is forcing you to make a very specific spell, apart from early on when you have but few runes.

Puzzles are encountered out and about in the open world, as well, and tucked into corners, tents and shops. These are usually solved without too much difficulty, so long as you have the right rune--and a magical fountain will usually be present to let you know whether you have them or not, as well as offer you more hints as long as you're willing to pay in-game currency, which is plentiful enough.

This brings me sadly to the issues I had with the game. This will bring us into heavy spoiler territory, so read at your own risk. [spoiler] The plot of Mages of Mystralia goes beyond the game itself, as I've stated before, but many haven't read the comic--I know I have yet to do so. As such, the game introduces characters, such as a young necromancer, but leaves their involvement in later events a complete mystery. A brilliant twist at the end, presenting a new villain, sets up a climactic confrontation, only to abruptly cut to a cutscene and credits, hinting at a possible sequel that may never come. As I'm typing this, I'm reading that the last announcement regarding further installments appears to be two years ago. It saddens me to see a story that had such potential close with such an abrupt tone, like a book slamming shut when you're getting to the last five chapters. Another disappointment I had was with the limitation regarding spell elements, with a full magical arsenal of fully varied elemental spells being available only when you were preparing for the final dungeon, which turns out to contain not one puzzle, but rather four rooms of element-themed enemies and a boss confrontation (which was admittedly quite bracing!) [/spoiler] The way the game sets up an arsenal only to give you a single chance to use it at full potential--no NG+, even, which would be an excellent addition to a game with this setup--is a little frustrating.

It feels to me as if this game wants to be bigger but did not have the resources to grow beyond its current size, which is quite sad. I hope that the Mystralia family do manage to bring us future installments, or even DLC. That being said, even with its present size and state, it is well worth buying, even at full price. You can buy a hearty McDonald's meal for two for twenty dollars, and this game will give you [i]much[/i] more enjoyment over [i]much[/i] more time. 

PROS:
+ Excellent worldbuilding, engaging plot
+ Terrific soundtrack
+ Creative, innovative gameplay that lets you craft your own spells
+A wild and varied world with intriguing dungeons and tricky puzzles

CONS:
-Feels polished, but rushed toward the end
-Some questions remain unanswered, and not always in the best ways
-Camera perspectives make movement just a little tricky in more cramped dungeons

I would give Mages of Mystralia two thumbs up and four and a half stars out of five, this game stole my heart and even its shortcomings don't stop me from loving it all the same. God bless you all and have a blast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198383285635', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1594863653}
review: Le jeu est vraiment captivant et la musique est magnifique!

author: {'steamid': '76561198121957391', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1587938088}
review:
The game has a good concept of crafting spells and creating increasingly complex spells throughout the game. Unfortunately, the dull enemy design and simplistic bosses render much of the spell-crafting useless. It doesn't matter how fancy the spells is if the enemies die to a much more simple one all the same. 

Many if not most of the spell-crafting components are given as rewards for optional exploration. This is a problem as areas are painfully dull and unchanged upon returning for forgotten items and scouring every square inch of a pretty but uninteresting map is not a good experience. 

Traversing the map is uninteresting and the slow movement makes this matter even worse. A dash spell is given early on, but it doesn't change the fact that a large portion of the game is spamming the dash function to get through empty maps with repeated enemies that respawn off screen. 

I had high hopes and tempered expectations for this game, and it was a complete let down dressed up in a cutesy ribbon. This game might be enjoyable for children, though many of the puzzles are quite challenging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073705474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 687, 'last_played': 1589853261}
review: fun little game, worth playing. I didn't 100% it or even get all the spell runes, but I completed the main story then did a few more side quests and feel like I did everything worth doing in the game. There isn't really much here. would prefer it to be much larger. Hell, the main story is so short I didn't even realize I finished it and was surprised when the credits rolled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035831897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1497, 'last_played': 1589615355}
review:
Just over 17 hours to 100% complete for me.  Good story, really nice spell system with the runes - it's the little changes based on what's connected to what that really show how well thought out the system is.

The life and mana upgrades, the different wands to change playstyles, I really enjoyed this. I'll probably keep this installed to dust off a bit later on a higher difficulty. Try and experiment more with the rune system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073636789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1591358229}
review:
Una joya oculta de esas que cuando te la encuentras no comprendes como no es mÃ¡s conocida. Mages of Mystralia es un juego con una jugabilidad fantÃ¡stica que mezcla combates con resoluciÃ³n de puzles de una manera muy acertada.  Para salir adelante tendremos que ir poco a poco desbloqueando conjuros diferentes y sus numerosisimas modificaciones. Pero no bastarÃ¡ con desbloquearlos, habrÃ¡ que combinarlos con ingenio para tener Ã©xito.

Lo recomiendo encarecidamente a cualquiera al que le gusten los juegos de acciÃ³n y aventura. Es muy divertido y original. Si lo veis en oferta ni lo dudeis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198228190400', 'num_games_owned': 846, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1589225522}
review: While it's definitely not the game for me and not that much for my taste, Mages of Mystralia is a neatly made adventure game for kids and younglings. Neat visuals, easy controls, colorful settings and characters, it looks like a game that many might enjoy. Not to my taste, but I do recognize a well crafted product here. Gets a 70/100 from me even though I played less than one hour.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971043225', 'num_games_owned': 1392, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1589109064}
review:
Awesome spell combination system and puzzles that require mastering it.
The level design is awesom and makes the backtracking a lot less annoying.
While the story is pretty basic, the gameplay easily makes up for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100984502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1674442368}
review:
I've only put a little over and hour in the game.  That said, it starts out a bit slow, and slowly picks up pace.  I just started spell customization and found it to bring about different ways to play the game.  Overall I find this game enjoyable.  My reasoning for this is simple.  I don't have a lot time to play so in this game I load it up play for 15 - 20 minutes and then I'm done.  Mages of Mystralia has save points everywhere and I don't feel like I need to read a source book or instructions to remind myself about how the game works.  So for casual gamers I give this a thumbs up. 

I wanted all mention

author: {'steamid': '76561198116731104', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1771, 'last_played': 1588913902}
review:
I'm sad that I can't recommend MoM to anyone but game designers. While the spellcrafting system is fun to play around with, it fails to prop up the dull enemy design. I 100%ed and got all achievements but one (more on that later). The game looks nice (though not great), the music is enjoyable for the time you'll likely spend in the game, and the story/world, while generic, is enjoyable enough.

The biggest letdown for me is the combat system. The very beginning of the game highlights this for me; up to the second boss, you have very little spellcrafting ability and the combat is boring because the enemies are boring. They either hit you in melee or throw a thing at you, and that's about it. 
The mage's motto is something like "when in trouble, a mage always crafts the perfect spell". This fits the spell puzzles, which can challenge you to think laterally and use your magery in novel ways. When it comes to enemies, their only trick is being entirely immune to one element, which is essentially clerical to deal with considering you can swap elements on the fly (and once you get an elemental wand, it doesn't matter anyway). The fact that you don't have the same puzzle feeling with the combat really defeats the purpose of it for me.

The next thing is the difficulty. After beating the second boss you gain your first trigger rune, which immediately takes you from Mickey Mouse in Fantasia to Dr. Manhattan. This massive breakpoint means that for the rest of the game, enemies become little more than an annoyance, and even bosses are just health bars that take 4 fireballs to kill. The one achievement I didn't get was using a scarab (get out of death free card) in a boss fight, because I was unstoppable by the time I got my first one, and I was playing on Archmage (hard) mode. The frustrating thing is that this power could have felt appropriate if the enemies required a more tactical approach.

My list of nitpicks to round it out:
[list]
[*] The game is not designed for mouse and keyboard. Worst when using the dash spell.
[*] You can and will fall off most ledges. Exacerbated by the first point.
[*] The levels can be like mazes, difficult to remember where things were.
[*] The map sucks. This makes getting lost frustrating.
[*] Limited teleporters means you're going to be running through a few loading screens to get where you want.
[*] You can get body-blocked and/or stunlocked. Especially in the first boss stages. Lightning dash is only bandaid.
[*] The story ends too abruptly. There is no final boss.
[/list]

Feel free to ask questions or proffer opinions. Stay civil.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971115479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1590626930}
review: nice and relaxing game for after work

author: {'steamid': '76561197994863173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1588856471}
review:
I have completed the game but have not found 100% of the secrets and puzzles (68% after doing a generally thorough play through without much backtracking).

[b]What's good about this game? (in no particular order)[/b]
- I never hold a bad story against a video game as I don't expect them or particularly desire them. I will never play a video game [i]because[/i] of its story but the story here is fairly decent. There's no twists and turns but it's coherent and well laid out. Ed Greenwood is top tier talent and it shows.
- Making broken spells is fun and pretty much the entire game. The beginning of the game when you have four basic spells and no components is actually pretty bad gameplay but if you power through it and get some triggers that let your spells cast more spells and so on then the gameplay gets interesting and fun. By the end of the game you are shooting spells that copy themselves on cast and on hit and at random times as they fly and spawn endless thunderstorms that drop fireballs. It's madness and the sky is limit. As long as your mana bar can hold out you can do whatever crazy thing you like.
- Controls are intuitive and functional. Games like this often struggle to make good control schemes and this one works out pretty well. You have four buttons that cast a spell of each type and then your spellbook can hold up to six custom spells you make of each type and a button can be used to swap between them in combat that works as well as can be expected. This game is meant to be played with a controller and works well with those controls. I have no idea how well it works on a keyboard but I assume it wouldn't work well without an analog stick.

[b]What's bad about this game[/b]
- THE CAMERA: Good god. What were they thinking? This is the single worst part of this game and it almost made me put it down after a couple hours. The camera is on rails and follows your character around in a forced isometric perspective which makes aiming spells impossible (without the game's auto aim, which is sometimes rather finicky) and better yet, the world is not two dimensional. Things are [i]happening[/i] in three dimensions. Flying enemies are in the air. Projectiles fly around in arcs. You can't figure what ANY of it is doing because the camera is stuck in a perspective that makes telling what is going on impossible. The entrance to one dungeon in particular (the quarry) is almost impossible to find because of the camera's forced perspective. What should be blindingly obvious to your character is hidden from the view of the player at the bottom right of the screen and it's just overall a huge problem.
- Dotted around the world in most areas you will find lanterns that automatically save your progress. These are never not irritating because they save your game when you would rather not save it can occasionally not save it when you would rather save (leaving you running back and forth in their proximity trying to trigger them). These aren't a huge strike against the game so much as they are entirely unnecessary. The game could have just had standard saving from the menu like a normal game and it would have been better for it.
- The graphics are garbage. I don't think there is any kind of anti aliasing going on and if most models have been textured (as opposed to just being comprised of flat colored polygons) I cannot tell. A major character called The Enchanter is some kind of snake man or something but you can't make out what he actually looks like until the final scene of the game when the camera zooms in on his face. Every time the camera zooms in on Zia's face and it makes one cringe. The ONLY excuse for these things is that 99% of the game you are zoomed so far out from everything (see above about the camera) that you can't see a damn thing anyway and so details don't matter. Zia might as well be a featureless green cube with a red circle on top.

[b]Miscellaneous notes about the game that are not necessarily good or bad[/b]
- The early game before you get a lot of spell runes is extremely frustrating. Damage from your attacks feels insufficient and most enemies are able to attack you at a range. Many will engage you even when off-screen making fighting (thanks camera!) back difficult as they fire upon you with laser perfect accuracy while you can't even see them. Once you get spell runes and start building a few attack spells though this problem disappears entirely and feels satisfying to overcome. No need to see an enemy when you have duplicating homing bouncing fireballs of death.
- Enemies all come in four elemental flavors: Earth, air, water, and fire. Earth type enemies are [i]generally[/i] generic non-magical whatevers but the elemental affinities of monsters are very difficult to comprehend at first glance. Some enemies of a particular element are immune to spells of that element. Some are not. Example: Almost ALL yellow monsters are immune to electricity and tornado attacks of all varieties but I have yet to meet a fire enemy immune to fireballs. Weaknesses are easy to figure out and apply generally but a lot of times it's just not worth it to make a spell into the right element when a wave of fireballs is going to kill whatever it is anyway. In general I found myself caring about enemy elements less because of how they would resist my attacks and more about the kinds of attacks they would make in return (and I personally find air/electric enemies to be the most annoying for both). Aside from there's not a ton of enemy variety in the game: Melee goblins, ranged goblins, big ranged goblins, even bigger melee goblins, summoner goblins, skeletons, slimes, things that pop up and shoot things at you, eyeballs with wings, bugs that crawl towards you and explode, and giant scorpion bug things with armor plates. I think that's all the enemies in the game.
- The difficulty of the game is rather inverted. The game starts fairly difficult and then gets easier as your spells become insanely broken. The first two bosses are actually somewhat difficult while the rest of the bosses and the final boss I was able to complete on the first try without losing much health. Even the "Mage's Challenge" is trivial after a certain point.
- The game is rather short. I completed it in 13 hours and felt like I dragged my feet and goofed around a lot.

[b]Final verdict[/b]
Overall an interesting game with a fun concept. If you can stomach the horrible camera and ass-tastic graphics there is a good game in there. I would recommend buying it on discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203860083', 'num_games_owned': 732, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1656862598}
review:
I have a bit I can say about this game. My thoughts of whether or not to recommend have gone up and down throughout playing. In the end the game really did win me over, and I'm confident in my decision to recommend.

Please note that I played on "Mage" Mode
Pros:
-Game mechanics and design are fun and unique (albeit sometimes a bit stiff)
-Boss designs are very cool and create a good sense of urgency and "fear"
-Health pickups are well balanced, not too many to make the game too easy but you can walk around and find some around when you need them
-Animation isn't polished or AAA quality, but the heart is visible. Similar to a Wind Waker feel
-Runes and spell building makes the game more engaging and fun
-Rune puzzles were a good challenge but not impossible
-Kinda dumb thing but I really liked the wand designs. Reminiscent of Key Blades.

Cons
-The writing. Oh my gosh the writing. Whoever wrote this clearly got very into his/her lore and had great passion for it. That's great. BUT OH MY GOD PLEASE STOP. Paragraphs in tiny little dialogue boxes. Stories that aren't integral to the gameplay and are not optional. Lack of true "voices" for the characters: not in voice acting ways, but in "no one would ever actually say this" ways. I skipped a vast majority of the dialogue after halfway through the game because after a while I JUST DID NOT CARE.
-Stupid little thing: enemy speed. Maybe I wasn't playing in a while that is "normal" but I spent a lot of time kiting enemies while they tailed right behind me and had to wait until I was just enough away that I could turn around and attack.
-Slow and, not to be rude, but boring beginning. I'm glad in the end that I stuck through it, but it was a tough go for a bit
-Cut scenes were random and felt unnecessary. 
-Another stupid thing but Zia's voice effects drove me crazy. 

All in all, I feel like this is a good debut game. It's not perfect by enemies, but at the end of the day I enjoyed my time playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032407070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 645, 'last_played': 1588399612}
review: Great game.  Minor issues with weird planes.  Puzzles aren't too overdone/ nauseating.  Great combat mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107356006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1588353626}
review:
tl;dr, The game just falls flat. The spell customization doesn't make it feel powerful, you're still using basically the same spells on the same enemies in the same way over and over again. Other aspects of the game are also lackluster. Music lacks punch and atmosphere, controls are a little clunky, and the story is forgettable and unsatisfying.

In terms of what the game does well, the customization system is very cool and has huge potential that just isn't realized this time around. Seriously, it could be so so cool, but I just never felt powerful even when I had unlocked almost all of the parameter changes and heavily experimented with all my options. I definitely had an efficient system for quickly dispatching enemies, but that's not the same as feeling like all the enemies had a real reason to fear me, which is how you should feel by the end of a game like this. 
The other really good thing about this game were the puzzles, both the spacial door-locking puzzles and the ones where you had to customize your spells to complete them. They were what really took advantage of how the customization worked in this game, which is a shame because most of the game is combat and not puzzles.

So, yeah, if you really like the idea behind what's going on here, I recommend picking it up as it is enjoyable enough and sets the stage for a potentially killer sequel. If you aren't really invested in the intent of what the developers wanted you're not missing much if you skip this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198828589095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1150, 'last_played': 1591695932}
review: Veramente bello. Un po prevedibile come trama ma l'ho apprezzata comunque. E un ottimo miscuglio tra roguelike e rompicapo. Da soddisfazione cercar di ottenere delle combinazioni di effetti che massimizzino il danno minimizzando i cosi in mana. Ci sono dei piccoli bug ma niente di veramente rilevante o che il gioco non risolva da se. Lo consiglio caldamente

author: {'steamid': '76561197968570791', 'num_games_owned': 851, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1593120984}
review: If you liked Hob you will like this.  Some of the puzzles can be frustrating at first but just remember that you gain more tweaks to your spells as you go on and you can always come back and try them again later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011299777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1588184239}
review: Very fun game with a super in depth and interesting spell system once it gets going, but even on hardcore i can abuse the spell system early on to basically melt enemies, and the targeting system on m+kb has some issues at time. But its a huge testiment to the value of its system that i kept optimizing my spells, making new ones and finding uses for new spells. Plus using my broken spells were still fun as shit cause they weren't TOO broken, and i felt rewarded for using the systems well.

review:

Un petit jeu d'aventure avec une construction de sort trÃ¨s jouissif. Vous allez expÃ©rimenter des combinaisons pour aussi bien vous battre avec des sorts adaptÃ©s Ã  votre style crÃ©Ã©s vous-mÃªme, ou Ã  certains types d'ennemis, tout autant que vous allez devoir rÃ©soudre des Ã©nigmes en construisant des sorts ou une combinaison de sorts adaptÃ©s Ã  l'Ã©nigme.

Si le systÃ¨me est simple au dÃ©but, il se complexifie au fur et Ã  mesure que l'on rÃ©colte des runes.

L'aventure en elle-mÃªme est sympa, assez longue pour pouvoir profiter de la construction des sorts, restant assez courte pour Ã©viter de s'y ennuyer.

PS : Le temps steam affichÃ© n'est pas le bon, compter une moyenne de 10 Ã  15 heures d'aventures.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985170361', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1473, 'last_played': 1587969451}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013728022', 'num_games_owned': 543, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1587916574}
review: Excellent fun. Good art style and design. The in-game lore is ambitious but felt like it was being force fed to me. The final level frustrated me a little at the beginning but it encouraged me to great a good enough spell to help me out. Which is another awesome part of the game; spells can go through almost any combination imaginable with Mana cost providing the limitations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098511004', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1101, 'last_played': 1587832356}
review: Such a great game! About 14-16h if you're a completionist. I loved the creative magic system, it's probably my favourite thing about this game. Graphics are great, very stylised. I'd love to see what they could do with a bigger budget for a second one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198097298596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1188, 'last_played': 1587836131}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039827510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1447, 'last_played': 1514331421}
review:
I have completed the game at 100%.

Pros :
- Unique spells customization mechanic which makes gameplay very fun then
- Lot of diversity in level design / bestiary - boss are cool with nice mechanics
- Short puzzles based on the spells craft mechanic (unnecessary to continue the story though, you won't get stuck)

Cons :
- It's a bit short, but based on the price you can't expect 30h+.

CCL : a really nice game worth it's price

author: {'steamid': '76561198037385891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1582997748}
review: Recommended because it's clear the game is well made and designed - the cutesy-wootsy cartoony aesthetic isn't for me, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067079464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1587388693}
review: Got this in a Humble Bundle. Story is about 6 - 7 hours and gameplay is pretty good. There are secrets and additional spell modifiers to search for once the game is finished but there isn't really a reason to search for them as there is nothing to do once the story is done. Overall a good story game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017950548', 'num_games_owned': 737, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1587311954}
review: Really sincere, charming game. I enjoyed the spellcrafting element a lot more than I thought I would - usually, these systems feel too fiddly to me, but not here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007680839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1582929068}

author: {'steamid': '76561198967876089', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1662079524}
review:
Great cute little game! 

-Very colorful, with beautiful music that isn't overbearing. 
-Not quite a platformer (to me anyway, because you can't jump), but definitely an adventure with puzzle elements. The puzzles are just hard enough to make me feel like I'm not being handed rewards while also keeping the game challenging. 
-The spellcrafting can be difficult to wrap your head around, but really cool once you get the hang of it. 
-LOVE the battle mechanics. I can't stand turn-based battle, so this melee style is wonderful.

I'm really enjoying playing this for hours at a time, and would gladly pay for it if I hadn't received it as a gift.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970590776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1587145734}

Je suis trÃ¨s partagÃ© quand Ã  son intÃ©rÃªt. Son principal attrait en ce qui me concerne a Ã©tÃ© la nostalgie de Zelda Link to the past auquel j'avais jouÃ© avec passion il y fort, fort longtemps.
Car oui, je me suis forcÃ© Ã  jouer et Ã  finir le jeu, je n'y ai pas pris beaucoup de plaisir.
Donc, je suis mitigÃ©, mais si vous cherchez un Zelda like nostalgique, ce jeu pourrait vous satisfaire.

review:
Jeu sympa mais pas exceptionnel, Ã  prendre en solde. 

Le jeu est globalement bon, que ce soit niveau gameplay, musiques, graphique. C'est un petit jeu sympa, mais c'est tout. Il faut compter une quinzaine d'heures pour terminer le jeu Ã  100% en difficultÃ© moyenne.

Le gameplay de base est correct mais trÃ¨s perfectible.
 
Le personnage principal manque de souplesse. Deux sorts ([spoiler]Dash + Clone[/spoiler]) corrigent un peu Ã§a, mais Ã§a reste moyen. C'est d'autant plus frappant car on est rÃ©guliÃ¨rement confrontÃ© Ã  5-10 ennemis en mÃªme temps. Et c'est sans compter que beaucoup d'ennemis attaquent Ã  distance et avec une bonne prÃ©cision, infligent des effets nÃ©gatifs (gel, silence, brÃ»lure) et quelques uns ont tendance Ã  Stunlock (et Ã§a c'est un gros point nÃ©gatif).

Le systÃ¨me pour composer les sorts est bien mais je trouve que Ã§a reste un peu opaque sur certains aspects. MÃªme en passant pas mal de temps Ã  expÃ©rimenter on peut facilement passer Ã  cÃ´tÃ© de bonnes combinaisons si on ne comprend pas bien comment le systÃ¨me fonctionne. 

Les Ã©nigmes sont globalement bien faites, mÃªme si certaines m'ont paru difficile Ã  cerner Ã  cause des sorts attendus. Heureusement certaines Ã©nigmes sont facilement passables grÃ¢ce aux sorts de zone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971107115', 'num_games_owned': 677, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2059, 'last_played': 1594030035}
review:
Disclosure:  A friend of mine gave me a copy of this one because he's a nice guy.  Sometimes.  ;)

I've got 39 hours into this game, and a big chunk of that was two sittings.  It's pretty darn good.  When you look to see if you turned off that lamp, and the sun's coming up?  Yeah, it's that kind of game.

Ed Greenwood, creator of the Forgotten Realms, co-wrote this game, and it shows.  It's got a delightful flavor, a story I haven't quite finished, and don't want to spoil.  I'm not sure if this game is longer than I expected, or shorter; it feels short, but those 39 hours say it was engrossing enough I lost track of time more than once.

The store page is there to tell you what it is -- a top-down spellcasting adventure a little like Magicka Light, or the first Legend of Zelda.  You don't build your spells in real time, there's a pause menu for "preparing spells".  And the devs gave you a fairly free hand to work with it, though you unlock powers and flexibility gradually, providing a nice learning curve.  Easy to understand, but if you're devious, you can spend hours mastering it, and create some true monsters of spells.  (My favorite is called "Recursive Chain Fireball"...)

If you like charming games, just buy it.  If you like adventure games, just buy it.    If you like games at all, you'll probably like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164155079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1680939827}
review: Fun game that is very Zelda inspired. Although it feels a bit laggy with the movement, its something you get used to quickly. Combat system is also really nice! Although I must say that its not so easy to shift between spells so I do miss being able to bind them to a certain key.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046531858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1601582406}
review:
[h1]Have you ever wanted to be a wizard?[/h1]

You know, subtle and quick to anger, master of the arcane, wielder of the forces of creation! That kind of wizard! A true wizard!

Then like me you've most likely been frustrated by most "wizard" games out there. The only spells you can ever cast are the ones you buy off some vendor or learn as you level up. You can be powerful, yes, terrifyingly so even, but you're never the source of your magic. You're limited to what the devs thought of, and you don't feel like much of a Master Wizard when you can't even invent an entirely new kind of magic.

[b]Not so in Mages of Mystralia.[/b]

You start off with four spells. You end up with however many you were able to imagine and make work. Your basic shield spell becomes a spell where you dash and leave behind a stone statue that blows up if it's attacked. Your piddly "fire mine" spells becomes a classic wizard exploding fireball with some tweaking... if you're lame! Because why make a single fireball when you could cast a spell that throws out three fireballs that home in on enemies, bounce, explode, and [i]that casts itself on contact again and again and again until you probably run out of either enemies or mana?[/i]

Yes, it's exactly as awesome as it sounds.

This is a game that dares you to think big and forge your own way to play, and it pulls it off incredibly well. The execution is excellent, and the game is not shy at all about letting you come up with ridiculous spells that would break lesser games.

So put on your robe and grab your wand, and seign some weird and wonderful magic because you're a wizard, dammit, and wizards make choose their own paths.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169486891', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1586474501}
review:
I should first say that I'm recommending this game primarily because it has a lot of good ideas, not because it's a particularly great game in its own right. I'll also add that if you're looking for a game with a good story, you will be horribly disappointed with "Mages of Mystralia".

So I'll admit that I bought this entirely because of the way that it advertises its spell system. I am an absolute sucker for games that allow me a high level of customization and options to pick and choose from. In this regard "Mages of Mystralia" does really well. You can concoct some pretty crazy spells to help you out in combat. If anything, this makes the combat 'challenges' a bit too easy since it's easy to build some pure, grad-A cheese to nuke everything in a pretty short amount of time.

The main draw back of this system is that it's really obviously designed to be limiting. Most of it is combat-oriented apart from a few options that seem specifically designed to solve specific puzzles in the overworld. Whenever I found a spell construction challenge, it always felt less like me concocting a clever way to circumvent it, and more like me trying to guess what the designers were thinking.

Even coming up with the solutions to the puzzles in the late game didn't feel rewarding, as a lot of it came down to trying just every combination of things until the correct answer presented itself. For the depth that the game gives you... it also isn't long enough for you to explore all of the options organically forcing you to rub things on other things until something worked. As I said, good ideas with less than stellar execution.

The major down side to this game is the writing. You have a guy named "Mentor" who never mentors your character. Like... at all. You have a goblin that asks you to light his "braziers" which instead of being actual braziers are just camp fires. And of course the plot twist near the end is so mind-numbingly obvious that anyone who has consumed any media in the last 30 years should be genre savvy enough to see it coming.

Cool spell crafting system, gameplay that could maybe have been paced better, and writing that's just kinda cliche. All topped with a cliffhanger that doesn't make me care enough to buy the sequel that it's teasing. Whether it's worth your money depends largely on if you find the core spell crafting mechanic intriguing. Also, it's an easy game to 100% so that might also appeal to you if you're into Steam achievements. Otherwise, there are just better games out there for you to devote your time to.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964316172', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 656, 'last_played': 1585865380}

review: I spent about 11 hours to beat the game, including getting every single collectible in the game. By far one of the best smaller adventure RPG games I have played in years. author: {'steamid': '76561198123337201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1585598468}
review:
This is a fun action/adventure game that doesn't overstay its welcome and does enough different to feel original. If you're an experienced gamer, take the "Archmage" difficulty to make combat feel better. I had fun on Mage but it was very easy to cheese my way through all combat.

You play a young mage just learning your powers. Story is okay, nothing really stands out. You can probably see most of the twists coming. Gameplay and the puzzles in particular are where the game pays off. You have four basic spells you can cast at any time, a melee attack, a ranged attack, a shield/defense spell, and a persistent effect, mostly used for making ice bridges. You can modify spells with runes you unlock, letting you turn your ice bridge into a firey rain, turning your fireball spell into several homing lightning balls that explode, and several others. You can also assign "triggers," letting you automatically cast another spell as soon as the first spell hits. Naturally you can use this in combat to make specific spells. One enemy in particular chases you when you're not looking, and I had to modify a fireball spell to shoot out behind me. I added a trigger to the fire rain spell and made it absolutely devastating. But you can also use them to solve puzzle rooms.

These puzzle rooms are probably the most unique aspect of the game. You have several torches you need to hit in a short amount of time, and you need to modify your existing spells and add triggers so that they chain react and have the desired effect. It's kinda like a programming puzzle from a Zachtronics game at that point. It's pretty interesting and fun to solve them. I did "brute force" one puzzle, and I caught the game blatantly cheating on one when I tried solving it with fast reflexes before getting a specific rune. But it's a nice challenge.

Other puzzles are a bit less spectacular. There are the usual puzzles in a Zelda-like game, and I constantly found myself overthinking them. The solution is usually right there in plain sight and takes minimal effort. They're not bad, just a bit easy.

Combat is good, if a bit easy. Again, I was playing on an easy difficulty, so that's to be expected. I basically came up with one spell that threw a ton of electric balls out there very fast, and arc lightning-ed everything to death. On higher difficulties, you have more elemental resistances to balance. I rarely had that problem, and usually just changing the element of the one or two spells I constantly spammed was enough to solve it. Boss fights are the typical Zelda-like affairs, part boss fight and part puzzle. Once you solve the puzzle, the boss goes down very quickly. Again, a herder difficulty might be better for experienced players.

I'm not sure I'd recommend the game at $20. I got it in a bundle and had fun. Otherwise I might wait for a sale. But Mages of Mystralia offers a fun and pretty 2D Action/Adventure and is a great way to pass the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017086570', 'num_games_owned': 1433, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 879, 'last_played': 1585596055}
review:
It's like magicka, but instead of trying to conjure the spells spontaneously, you craft the spells you wanna use beforehand (or mid-fight). The spellcraft system is deep and fun to try to come up with the spells as you imagined. The art style and soundtrack are better than what I'd expected.
One thing I'd like to complain is that the early sections of the game feel a bit too tedious, with just how little you can do with spellcrafting.

Note:  if you can come up with an OP spell too early into the playthrough, the game will feel way less challenging even on the hard mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250013440', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1585424744}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009664950', 'num_games_owned': 2869, 'num_reviews': 345, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1585421069}
review: I eventually gave up on this game around the Sleet fight, but I think it's a good microcosm of why this game is so frustrating. The actual boss is fine- it has multiple attacks and phases, and you have to find its weak point, very standard and good. But the entire fight, these annoying skeletons spawn in. They can swarm you, whittle your life down to nothing in seconds, your spells take forever to finish them, and you have to hit them when they're down to actually kill them. I don't think that the boss itself ever actually killed me in the 10 attempts I made before giving up. It was always me running out of mana while trying to fight off the 20 or so skeletons swarming me and getting hacked to pieces. I think that sums up most of my problems with the game- all the ideas are compelling, but the baseline, moment-to-moment game feel and balance are fragile and messy. Customizing a wide arsenal of spells with programming-style conditional nodes is a great idea for a game, but it all means nothing if the baseline moving and hitting stuff gameplay is no good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004253864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1584842865}
review:
I've been looking for ages for a fun game with a great spellcrafting mechanic.

Here it is.
Puzzles, puzzle-rooms, bosses.
While the puzzle-rooms are generally designed for a specific combination, you can often get away without the intended rune with clever crafting.
You can be a cautious genius throwing the perfect spell, or some kind of barbarian mage dropping nukes everywhere.

My only criticism is that there isn't enough of it. I want more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032503176', 'num_games_owned': 1304, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1584768531}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 46119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46119, 'last_played': 1584634798}
review:
Mages of Mystralia feels somewhat like Magicka meets Zelda and ends up being actually quite a great game.

For an indie game it has plenty content and very different biomes to get through as well as a solid difficulty which isn't too high nor too difficult.

Featuring a very extensive magic system, great platforming and a somewhat unique art style, Mages of Mystralia was a very pleasant surprise to play for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214151885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1678145766}
review:
spell crafting metroidvania relatively easy boss fights due to broken rune combinations. what more could you ask for. (random rune OP)
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197969643946', 'num_games_owned': 931, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1584547143}
review:
A Zelda-like adventure game where you interact with your environment and perform combat with spells, which you get more and more customisation and control over as the game progresses.

Great soundtrack - very reminiscent of some Final Fantasy classics - which alongside some thoughtful cinematic camera work creates a surprisingly nice atmosphere.

They appear to have taken a relatively generic adventure framework and slapped on a bunch of stuff to make it really unique and enjoyable. Two thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198127133011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 343, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1584472544}
review: No me puedo creer que Mages of Mystralia sea indie. Me llamÃ³ la atenciÃ³n el sistema de magia en el trailer, pero no esperaba que realmente hubiesen profundizado tanto en la mecÃ¡nica de los hechizos programables. Es super divertido de usar y nunca deja de sorprenderte. En el resto de aspectos el juego presenta mucho pulido tambiÃ©n: el estilo visual me encanta, la banda sonora da en el clavo, el diseÃ±o de niveles me ha gustado bastante y no me he encontrado ningÃºn bug en toda la partida. Una verdadera joya.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145692025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 1584035860}
review:
Richtig schÃ¶nes Spiel! Und tolle Story!
Der malerisch schÃ¶ne Grafikstil hat mich sofort verlieben lassen :D
Dazu die Detailverliebtheit.. wenn man genau hinschaut, entdeckt man so viel!
Mit der spannenden Story und den vielen zu entdeckenden FÃ¤higkeiten und RÃ¤tseln hat Mages of Mystralia echt einen Suchtfaktor! :3
Bis zum Schluss des Games spannend. Hat mir sehr viel SpaÃŸ und Freude bereitet! 
Absolute Empfehlung von meiner Seite!

author: {'steamid': '76561198134228901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1583956472}
review:
Gioco assolutamente mediocre, si salva solo la grafica piuttosto carina.
Il gameplay Ã¨ orribile, buggato (pure in positivo, certi boss puoi batterli sfruttando l'invincibilitÃ  dopo la caduta) e la visuale fissa non aiuta. La trama all'inizio Ã¨ interessante, ma il finale Ã¨ la cosa piÃ¹ banale del mondo, con anche il pretesto becero per fare un seguito. infine la difficoltÃ  Ã¨ completamente a caso, sia per i bug che per il bilanciamento dei danni e della difficoltÃ  alla Dark Souls 2 (del tipo perchÃ© fare dei nemici impegnativi, basta metterne 20 ed ecco la sfida).

author: {'steamid': '76561198109708285', 'num_games_owned': 1860, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1213, 'last_played': 1583431577}
review:
Mi e' dispiaciuto quando e' finito.
Il gioco e' molto bello, combattimenti da fare con calma (a difficolta' elevata, almeno) e molto bello il sistema che ti permette di creare magie sempre piu' assurde (ma senza diventare troppo gesu). Grafica ispirata che ricorda una PS2 ad alta definizione (Jack and Dexter in particolare, per qualche motivo). Musiche davvero molto belle. Puzzle semplici ma simpa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076075636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 731, 'last_played': 1583843785}
review:
Nun habe ich "Mages of Mysteria" nach etwa 12 Stunden durchgespielt und muss sagen, dass ich nicht so ganz schlÃ¼ssig darÃ¼ber bin, ob ich das Spiel wirklich zum Kauf empfehlen kann. 

Hinweis: Ich habe im leichtesten Modus gespielt, auch weil es in verschiedenen Bewertungen so empfohlen wurde. Es ist durchaus mÃ¶glich dass sich einige Faktoren in schwierigeren Graden Ã¤ndern.

Es hat einige sehr interessante Aspekte, darunter die Tatsache dass man sich seine Zauber mit wÃ¤hrend des Spielens gefundenen Runen selbst zusammen stellen kann und damit viele unterschiedliche Kombinationen und Effekte mÃ¶glich sind. Will man lieber weniger Schaden machen und dafÃ¼r mehr Zauber wirken? Oder geht man in die vollen, die einen Raum mit mit wenigen Zaubern von Gegnern befreien? Beides mÃ¶glich, ich habe mich fÃ¼r letztere Variante entschieden. Dies bedeutet aber auch Ã¶fters darauf warten, dass das eigene Mana regeneriert wird (oder einen Manatrank zu sich nehmen). Wer ein bisschen Diabolo, Sacred oder Zelda gespielt hat, kennt das Ausweichen der Gegnerattacken schon und kann dementsprehend auch die Zeit, die zur Regeneration notwendig ist, Ã¼berbrÃ¼cken. Generell gefÃ¤llt es mir gut, dass es vier unterschiedliche Arten von Zaubern mit vier Elementen gibt, allerdings hatte ich den Eindruck, dass man mit einigen wenigen Kombinationen fast das ganze Spiel durchspielen kann. Dies trÃ¼bt natÃ¼rlich den Eindruck vom Spiel ein wenig. 
Es gibt neben den - taktisch leider eher anspruchslosen - KÃ¤mpfen im Spiel auch noch einige RÃ¤tsel, welche man mit entsprechenden Zaubern lÃ¶sen muss. Diese sind nett gemacht, aber variieren stark im Anspruch des KÃ¶nnens und Geschicks sowie wie man nun die einzelnen Runen miteinander verbindet. Manchmal wÃ¼nschte ich mir etwas besseres Feedback, manchmal mehr Anspruch und etwas wenig "gut GlÃ¼ck". Hier wurde meiner Meinung viel Potential verschenkt, diesen Faktor hÃ¤tte man deutlich ausbauen kÃ¶nnen.
Desweiteren gibt es auch RÃ¤tsel, bei welchen man TÃ¼ren Ã¶ffnen muss indem man Steine in einer richtigen Kombination zusammenlegt. Auch hier hÃ¤tte ich mir teils anspruchsvollere RÃ¤tsel gewÃ¼nscht sowie etwas mehr Belohnung. Oft bekommt man lediglich lila Perlen, mit denen man Mana und Lebensenergie verstÃ¤rken kann. Beides ist aber meiner Meinung nach ausreichend vorhanden. Hier ist ebenfalls ein Ausbau mÃ¶glich.
Kommen wir nun zu den Quests und der Story. Im Gegensatz zu anderen Bewertern empfand ich den Einstieg nicht als trÃ¶ge. Es ging langsam, man wurde behutsam in die Geschichte und die Welt eingefÃ¼hrt und dann hat es zur Mitte hin, auch mit weiteren Runenfunden, an Fahrt zugenommen. Es gab nette, kleine Quests, deren LÃ¶sung jetzt nicht Ã¼berragend schwer war. Gegen Ende des Spiels zeichnete sich aber eine gewisse ErmÃ¼dung ab, weil sich die Geschichte nicht wirklich weiterentwickelt. Recht bald wird auch klar, in welche Richtung die Geschichte geht, was es mit manchen Objekten und Charakteren auf sich hat. Es ist im besten Fall eine 08/15-Geschichte, wie man sie schon oft gesehen hat. Die Grundlage ist gut, es gibt aber in der Tat deutlich Verbesserungspotential. Vor allem Endet die Geschichte mit einem (kleinen) Cliffhanger, was ich selber nicht sonderlich mag. Ich hÃ¤tte mir mehr Geschichte gewÃ¼nscht, mehr Ã¼ber die HintergrÃ¼nde der Welt erfahren. Leider klebt das Spiel ziemlich an den Zelda-Spielen, deren Geschichten auch fÃ¼r mich zu WÃ¼nschen Ã¼brig lassen. Am Ende war ich als Spieler nicht wirklich befriedigt.
Negativ beeinflusst wird das Ganze durch die kleine Spielwelt, ich fÃ¼hlte mich vom Umfang her eher in einem Seitental im Schwarzwald als in einem richtigen Land, welches es zu retten gilt. Die durch Ladepausen abgetrennten Gebiete sind klein, zum Teil arg schlauchartig und sie Ã¤hneln sich zu oft.
Die Grafik gefÃ¤llt mir ziemlich gut, ich mag den Stil, allerdings hat man sich auch recht schnell daran sattgesehen und eine etwas lebendigere, abwechslungsreicheres Welt gewÃ¼nscht. 

Fazit:
Es war unterhaltsam, den Preis definitiv nicht wert. Wenn man es in einem Bundle oder sehr gÃ¼nstig bekommt, kann man es sich mal anschauen und an einem regnerischen Wochenende durchspielen, aber man sollte sich darauf einstellen, mit einem gemischten GefÃ¼hl aus dem Spiel zu gehen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039238163', 'num_games_owned': 6784, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1583684337}
review:
[h1]Welcome to PC Zelda-like kingdome[/h1]
The game was an unexpected surprise for me, but a welcome one. It has one of the best magic-systems i have ever seen and it would be enought to carry the whole game.

It's a game where you fight your way through areas and dungeons entirely using magic. But the unique aspect of this game is that you can craft your own spells! You have four basic spells and over the course of the game collect runes which alter these spells (from which you can save up to 6 presets each). And after a while, when you can chain spells to trigger other spells or even replicate themselves. You can have a basic fireball attack that shoots one ball straight forward. Or you can create a spell that launches a row of fireballs. You can add Runes that make the fireballs bounce off of walls, or home in on enemies, or turn in mid-air. Or you can create a spell that causes a close-ranged fire explosion. Besides getting new abilities for spell creation, you're able to find different wands that give you buffs or increase the attack damage of specific elements. Further, you can find upgrades to spend to increase your HP or Mana. Clearly, the spell system is the main focus here.

The story follows you being a good fantasy hero in order to protect the good magic users as the kingdom has banished them and is looking to get rid of them. You navigate a few NPC areas, and head through dungeons fighting sets of enemies and bosses as in a typical fantasy game. And of course, there are some puzzles for you to solve to get items or upgrades, some of which may only be available if you create specific spells.


ğŸ‘ Pros:

- Fun magic mechanics and gameplay
- Sound and music
- Charming atmosphere

ğŸ‘ Cons:

- Generic story

[b]Conclusion[/b]

[table]
    [tr]

[th]This game deserves a solid thumbs up and a recommendation since it have addictive mechanics and gameplay. Enjoyable zelda-like game.

My rating: 7.5/10[/th]
    [/tr]
[/table]

    [tr]

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/8463685/[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

author: {'steamid': '76561197986373795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1582514918}
review: Fun top-down action-adventure game, with a flexible spell creation mechanic. It starts with simple spells, and each rune you pick up increases your options exponentially. Not difficult, but it still makes you feel smart when you make a powerful combat spell, or the right combination to get your fireball to light a torch in a specific direction. Not too long, but worth the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061018281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1583019072}
review:
Very interesting spell crafting system.
That's pretty much all, the rest is forgettable.

I won't finish the game, I'm probably near the end but now have OP spells (crafting system is very interesting, as I said, but this kind of system must be very hard to balance) and it doesn't feel challenging anymore, so...

Thumb up for the spell crafting though, would love to see more games encouraging you to really play with their mechanics, like Mages of Mystralia does.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998455537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 809, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1583085289}
review:
Mages of Mystralia was a webcomic turned into a video game. The objective of the game is to get to the end of the story.

Gameplay-wise, WASD for movement, Spacebar/LMB/RMB/Left-Shift for powers, Tab for Map.

Top-down combat with ingenius spell combos. The spell combos are similar to Magicka, where you learn to combine 4 different base elements, wind(lightning), water, earth and fire.

Immedi is for fast melee spells or instantaneous spells, such as slashes and explosions.  

Actus is for spells with conditional durations, such as mines and projectiles.

Creo is for creation of surfaces and winds or spells with a durable effect, such as ice bridges and fire walls.

Egos is for shield type spells or spells affecting one's self, such as shields and fast movement. You can create shields, mirrors, dash, magnet and duplicates of yourself.

Conclusion, do try MOM. It's a veritable gem as verified by me. This review is one of the rare 14.9% that completed the game.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. The World
It's not a vast expansive world but it's pretty detailed and different.

2. The Creatures
Mechanically distinct. I liked how each of them had a different fighting style, in particular, the goblins. E.g. Shaman can catch fireballs and fire them back, bruiser can charge and smash, grunt hits, spearmen shoot, pig bomber runs around and bombs stuff.

3. The Puzzles
Connecting the dots, solving how to hit the target with fireballs, quest puzzles. Loved them.

4. Magic System
I loved the Magicka system of combining base magics to form new spells. You can find a similar system in Magicka but I don't think it's as good. Weird add-ons like Right or Left made me bemused.

5. Using the Magic
I loved how the Magic could be used to make platforms, create shields which can be modified into copies, etc 

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018293698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1582922478}
review:
The Zelda inspired indie game demographic is... crowded, to say the least. So I was pretty ready to dump Mages of Mystralia at the first sign of frustration. Indeed, as I played through the beginning I was already starting to get bored. Lightning spell, oh wait it's just a sword, fire spell, nope that's just the lantern, earth spell, hello shield. Yawwwwwwwn. But when I stumbled up the first spell rune I said, out loud, to an empty room, "oh damn, this game is actually good!" Why? Because Mages of Mystralia actually brought something new to the buffet of Zelda-likes, and that something was pretty damn cool.

Mages of Mystralia doesn't really have items per se, but most spells are mechanically identical to the classics i.e the examples above. I had assumed that as the game went on I'd get more spells replicating more suspiciously similar Zelda item effects. And that is essentially what happens, but Mystralia gets there in an infinitely more interesting way. There are actually only four real spells in the gameâ€”instead you're rewarded with spell runes that act as modifiers. You then junction these modifiers onto a limited hexagonal grid to change the spell behaviour. So the default earth spell is a shield, but junctioning a move rune onto it makes it a dash. Follow me so far?

Now, there are also modifiers for the modifiers. If we take our dash spell, we can junction on a time modifier to make the dash go further, or a teleport modifier to make our dash into more of an instant blink. Or we can do both. See where this is going?

But then Mages of Mystralia goes completely nuts by throwing in a bunch of trigger runes, which essentially allow you to junction spells onto spells onto spells. Now we can junction a melee attack spell to trigger when we blink into an enemy group, which is set up with an exploding, chain lightning effect, which has another spell junctioned to shoot five homing fireballs from each chained enemy's body at all the others caught in the mayhem, and those missiles have [i]another[/i] spell attached to... Well... you probably get it. And I didn't even get to the element shifting, which adds a whole other level of possibilities!

As long as your mana holds out, you can basically program your abilities to a completely absurd level of power. This is such an elegant, brilliant system that completely changed how I approached my adventure. Chests were exciting not just because they had a new rune, but because of the new spell combos that rune could potentially enable. It's like figuring out the A+B bomb arrow trick in Link's Awakening, except it works with almost any item the game throws at you.

So yeah, gameplay-wise alone Mages of Mystralia gets a big thumbs up, but that's not to say the rest of the game is bad. I'm decidedly not an Ed Greenwood fan, but having a professional writer means the world is a little bit more thought out than the average fantasy/retro/4th wall reference-packed settings you see in most indie action adventures. The world/dungeon/puzzle design is fairly tight, especially with all the shenanigans enabled by the spell rune system. The art is fineâ€”I particularly liked the style of the quasi-animated sequences bookending the gameâ€”and the music is good, particularly for the way it ebbs and flows with the action, feeling like a properly orchestrated cinematic score.

But none of that stuff would elevate a game with boring gameplay, so it's a good thing that  Mages of Mystralia's gameplay elevates everything else. A lot of games fail to make magic feel powerful, or dangerous or, well, magical, but there is none of those issues here. If the average top down sword swipey green hat dungeon crawler isn't doing it for you, try putting on your robe and wizard hat.
