review:
[h1]Welcome to Mystragicka![/h1]

Steckt da etwa eine Anspielung auf Magicka im Titel? Jawoll, meine Damen und Herren - die einen oder anderen unter Ihnen erinnern sich vielleicht: Das COOP-Magier-TopDown-Action-Abenteuer Ã¼berzeugte vor einiger Zeit mit zwei Ablegern seine Fangemeinschaft und lieÃŸ uns (un)gekonnt verschiedene Elementarzauber zu bunten neuen (un)nÃ¼tzen Effekten miteinander vermischen. Oft auch zu den eigenen Ungunsten.

In eine Ã¤hnliche Kerbe schlÃ¤gt "Mages of Mystralia", erinnert dabei aber mehr an Zelda und kombiniert geschickt eine "Quasi-Mini-Open-World" mit RÃ¤tseldungeons und einzigartigen Endbossfights. Dabei spielt Magie natÃ¼rlich die Hauptrolle - denn hier gilt es bestimmte Basiszauber wie Luft, Eis, Feuer und Blitz kreativ mit anderen VerstÃ¤rkern wie bspw. "Bewegen", "Links", "Rechts", "VerstÃ¤rken" oder gar "Kopieren" zu verÃ¤ndern - so wird aus einer starren Flamme plÃ¶tzlich ein nach rechts gedrallter Feuerball oder eine sich nach vorne ausbreitende Eisscholle. Die KombinationsmÃ¶glichkeiten sind vielfÃ¤ltig und fÃ¼r Experimentierfreunde gibt es allerhand auszuprobieren. Ich als Fan der Einfachheit verlor zunehmends den Ãœberblick und war geknickt, wenn ich gewisse SonderrÃ¤tselrÃ¤ume nicht mehr so einfach wie zu Beginn lÃ¶sen konnte - aber da auch die Belohnung recht unspektakulÃ¤r ausfiel sowie die Tatsache, dass ich recht fix am Ingame-Geld-Maximum angekommen war, sorgte neben der spannungsfreien Sprechblasenstory fÃ¼r sich langsam immer weiter ausgebreitete ErnÃ¼chterung. Leider konnte mich die Grafik auch nicht Ã¼berzeugen. Als ein wenig zu texturflach und polygonarm empfinde ich sie. Im Prinzip ein charmantes Indie-Game, aber mir fehlte auf Dauer das gewisse Etwas und die anfÃ¤ngliche BefÃ¼rchtung schnell im Zauber-Kombinationschaos zu enden, bestÃ¤tigte sich leider mehr und mehr.

Wem's gefÃ¤llt...

author: {'steamid': '76561198053926269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1679006344}
review:
A surprise to be sure, but a welcome one

Mages of Mystralia, Puzzle-RPG has one of the best magic-systems i have ever seen and it would be enought to carry the whole game. But wait, there is more.

First, the game is awefully cute, but deals with themes like racism etc. It sure is suitable for children, if they can bear the sometimes spiking difficulty, but it has something for everyone. A great soundtrack, nice looking worlds etc, etc.

Lets come to the magic. You have four basic spells and over the course of the game collect runes which alter these spells (from which you can save up to 6 presets each). You start mit a shield, a basic melee, a little flame and some ice. And after a while, when you can chain spells to trigger other spells or even replicate themselves, you cast ONE spell and just straightup eradicate every living creature in the room by itself replicating, homing, bouncing fireballs that explode into lightning on impact. It's fantastic. My mana is always empty.

The riddles are fun too, sometimes pretty hard, sometimes very easy, but never illogical. And you can even cheese some of them if you built your spells right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112641589', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1582361910}
review: I did not find this game very engaging. The way the narrative unfolds feels cheesy. I feel no connection with the characters. The spell combination was enjoyable, but the actual combat doesn't feel good. However, the art and music are awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040811698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 429, 'playtime_forever': 1005, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1583000642}
review: Imagine playing Zelda as if you actually were Zelda. Good action adventure with a focus on magic. Simple but fun, good customization for the spells, it all works together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148050229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1655771072}
review:
TLDR: 7.5/10; great art and gameplay, many gameplay customization options, lacking story and dialogue, highly recommend.

Pros:
Beautiful art for environment and gameplay animations. Extremely fun and highly customizable gameplay. There are different types of spells, and elements, that can be mixed and matched. Furthermore, there are many runes, each of which drastically change a spell's properties with synergies that feel extremely satisfying. Rewarding exploration; especially mid-game, every new rune feels like a dramatic boost in power and creative possibilities, and the wands give welcome bonuses that allow for either highly specific or very diverse playstyles.
 
Cons:
Not many cutscenes, but the animation for some of them is awkward. The story didn't really interest me beyond what you can get from the opening cutscene and the first couple minutes; upon arriving to Haven (the place that you immediately after a short tutorial section) it didn't seem important. There's a point where you're informed of [spoiler]your home village being burned down[/spoiler]; I just kinda went to the combat arena first. The dialogue also feels a bit off, and the ending left me thinking I got some sort of "bad ending," or like I could do some sort of epilogue. As far as I can find, there is only one ending.

Overall:
7.5/10. Unfortunately the cons are story based, and I love a good story in a game, but the gameplay totally carries the game to a highly enjoyable experience. A fairly unique game, at least out of what I have played. Good fun. Worth it if story aspects aren't 100% make-or-break for you; they're not game-ruining or anything, just somewhat disappointing. Would love a definitive edition, and/or a sequel (the ending is kind of sequel bait-y.) Highly recommend.

P.S. I got the game as a gift from a friend, not as any form of promotion from the devs. Having played it and knowing what it's like, I'd definitely buy it over anything else on my radar around or above this price.

review: A wonderful little game with really nice spellcrafting and puzzles to solve. Going into this blind the first 45 minutes almost had me uninstalling but I had not got to the spellcrafting portion yet. Glad to say it's a fun story with some exciting puzzles that range from super easy to frustratingly difficult. Beat game in 10hrs. Worth it on a humble bundle monthly pickup

review: I love the style of this game and really wanted to enjoy it. But I despise the combat in this game. It is very unfun and felt like I would have to slog through hours of crappy spells before I would become powerful enough to defend myself properly. The animations make some hits feel super cheap and you die super fast. Big points for style, but killing things is unsatisfying and overly difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993023804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1581280051}
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#159 out of 555)... it's time for Mages of Mystralia.

Of all the games I've recieved as parts of bundles, Mages of Mystralia surprised me the most. I was expecting a relatively simple ARPG. I was not expecting a genuinely complex spell customization system, and I especially wasn't expecting Nintendo-level charm.

Yeah, I know. I have a hard time believing what I just said, too. Obviously they don't have Nintendo's budget, so it's not as polished as a headline Zelda or Mario might be. But the well thought-out mechanics? The level design? The art style? The animation? The bosses that make you sit up in your seat and think, "Wow!" That's all here. Definitely one of the best action-adventure RPGs I've had the pleasure to play, and the first game I've seen since Okami that genuinely evoked that Nintendo feel. This game oozes charm and if your fond of the genre or intrigued by the promise of a deep and highly customizable magic system, you owe it to yourself to give Mages of Mystralia a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093603927', 'num_games_owned': 2139, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1310, 'last_played': 1581783729}
review:
You get some games where you will wander off and do side quests... This is a game where I wandered off and made spells!
I was so enthralled with the combinations and the possibilities, that I totally gave up on the story just so that I could re-play an area with a new spell I had made!

There are some negatives. 
The game can be buggy (can't aim up) 
The enemies aren't as balanced as we would all like (being stun-locked by multiple attackers at once sucks)
Once you hit max cash, you just stop gaining anything

You can't skip cutscenes
Very linear gameplay

All of this pales in comparison with how amazing the spell crafting system is.
You can go from a fire mine to a fire ball, to a homing fireball, to a fireball that will re-cast itself when it hits a target, to all of that, but now there's THREE of them! (and this is just the one spell)
You will find yourself crafting spells just for a specific puzzle (which is a lot of fun too!) but you'll also make a set of spells for combat that you will always be battling between 'I WANT MORE' and 'I can't afford to cast it more than once'

The storyline is a little simple and, I confess, I did not care much about any of the characters (other than [SPOILER] that Zia gets right at the beginning) but there is clearly a lot of lore hidden in here. I would love to see much, much more about this world and it's inhabitants.

Once you have gained 100%, your spells are epic, your health and mana ought to be maxed out and you feel like an unkillable badass versus about everything you face... and yet you can STILL be killed by the very first enemies you meet! You don't level up, you just get better and learn more spells.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086881034', 'num_games_owned': 623, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1250, 'last_played': 1581707666}
review: Good

author: {'steamid': '76561198046243811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1581701794}
review:
This game looks like it'll be great fun, with what is clearly a very well thought-out spell system and some cool puzzles. It also looks kinda cute.

However, I just cannot deal with the utterly awful combat. It really [i]feels[/i] like it should have an ability-cancel, a dodge button, and basically a lot sharper and more responsive controls. But it doesn't. It really doesn't. You're [i]very[/i] slow - and worse, your hitbox is significantly bigger than your actual model. 

As a result, combat is a mess. You can very easily get stuck between a couple of enemies, and stun-locked into extinction. You can't easily get away from enemies, or dodge between them. Your attacks are slow, and can't be cancelled.

Just over two hours in, I found a combat challenge room which was beyond infuriating. About 8 enemies in a very small space, which you can fall/be knocked off. You do not have a dash which can pass through enemies. Three of the enemies have AoE attacks which freeze you. One of them is big, and has a rush attack which cannot be blocked, and can push you off the edge. If you fall off, you lose a significant chunk of health and spawn back... without any i-frames, meaning you can immediately be knocked off again, if they happen to rush again. Most criminally of all, if you die, you spawn back several rooms (with respawning enemies between you). 

Who thought this was [i]possibly[/i] a good idea? Genuinely made me put the controller down and and step away from the game out of pure frustration for poorly-thought-out mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020613938', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1614548282}
review: I tried this game for the magic system, which is clever, but doesn't seem to be progressing as fast as the game indicates the content is being consumed.  That expectation aside, the game is stable, engaging and the combat is reasonably challenging.  It can be a little frustrating as actions and attacks can leave you prone... and the mobs can chain them to keep you that way.  The puzzles tend to depend on either reflexes or progression, which can be frustrating if you challenge them too early.  Overall, though, I intend to keep playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110812452', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1612889297}
review:
I fairly enjoyed this game. 
The way spell works is a fun thing although some things take time to figure out how to do.
I only fell out of the world because of a glitch once in this game but I didn't get any penalty from it.
You also in some places were able to make some enemies fall through the ground because of their animations and other enemies collisions' box.
But I was never soft locked in this game unlike other games.
it could still be improved on.
The start seemed kind of slow and the last half of the game was very fast.
I like the look and feel of the world and the characters.
the controls (Xbox controller) felt nice to use. The only place where the controls could be a bit weird to use was in the spell building sections but you get used to it.
The puzzles also seem very fun but some you can be solve easier than what was expected.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970884962', 'num_games_owned': 837, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1688, 'last_played': 1581532956}
review:
Beautiful game with a very clever spell combination system. Well worth a few hours of your time. 

Be careful with the difficulty setting. The lowest difficulty (Mage Mode) is very easy but the next step up (Archmage mode) is much harder with new types of harder enemies and more difficult puzzles. I don't recommend Archmage mode for a first play through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120689919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1581543076}
review: I got this game from a friend yesterday, and i must say i loved every minute of it so far. This takes me back to the childhood and games like Spyro.  The gameplay is very good, and addictive. The graphics are very nice, although i'm not personally the fan of how the character faces are modelled, but most of the time you get a top-dow view so this is hardly an issue. The environments are stunningly beautiful. The only real downside i have found so far are the loading screens, which strongly differ from the game's artstyle, and kinda pull you out of the experience. Other than that, the game is amazing and addictive, and i would definitely buy it full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022868355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1581490925}
review: a wonderful short game. beautiful old school feeling graphics. And hours of amusement figuring out all the crazy powerful spells you can craft, or just crazy spells. Archmage mode gave a good mix of fun and challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007513026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 433, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1581637266}
review:
This is so close to being a good game but a balance issue ruins the game play for me.

Graphics, puzzles and enemy variety are excellent. Its a huge game with interesting areas to explore.

What spoils it is the developers have made the boss monster battles too frustrating for someone like me who doesn't have good arcade game skills. Also, there is a frustrating delay programmed in when a monster hits, what were they thinking? 

You can turn down the difficulty but only at the start of the game. Others have reported that turning down the difficulty one step removes all the arcade challenge, that is not want I want. I'm not going to restart the game from the beginning just to check whether I want to play a story only game, better to move onto a well designed game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041169329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 963, 'last_played': 1581248812}
review:
I have a soft spot for games that allow players to craft and configure their own spells and this one scratches that itch nicely. It's a fun concept executed very well, with no polish issues found in my playthrough, with a very "A Hat in Time" aesthetic if that appeals to you and a nice soundtrack.

10/10 would chain lightning everything into oblivion again

author: {'steamid': '76561197977048333', 'num_games_owned': 1641, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1580986551}
review:
Solid indie game! You play as an apprentice-mage who's protecting the valley from grave danger. Story is simple but you can't say the same about gameplay. As an apprentice-mage you start with few basic spells but the more you play, the more runes you get and more powerful you become. Mages of Mystralia offer unique spell crafting system that allows you to change basic spells in the way you like it. For example: you can recreate your basic fire spell into fireball and by adding "at once" and "duplicate" rune you will be able to cast deadly wave of fireballs. Later you will get an acces to elements tab that will allow you to change core-element of your spells (for example fireball can be transformed into snowball that can freeze your enemies). You will have to use right combination of spells to fight enemies (some of them are resistant to certain type of damage) and to solve environmental puzzles (some are quite challenging!).
Graphics looks nice but simple. I didn't encounter serious bugs or another technical issues.
If I had to look for weak spots I'd say that world map is pretty useless and there could be more enemies (you basically fight goblins all the time) and items (I finished the game with full pockets because there were nothing to spend cash on). Also final fight could be more challenging... I had more trouble getting on top of the tower than defeating the final boss. 
Overall it's pretty solid game. If you like playing as a mage you should buy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042050794', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1581245332}

Mages of Mystralia kommt anfangs ganz unscheinbar daher. Die Dialoge sind recht hÃ¶lzern, die PrÃ¤sentation ist generisch und das Spielprinzip scheint auch nichts Besonderes zu sein. Wenn man es aber schafft ungefÃ¤hr 40-60 Minuten bei der Stange zu bleiben, entpuppt sich das Spiel zu einem echt interessanten Abenteuerspiel mit vielen Anleihen von Zelda, Metrovanias oder Diablo.

Neben den KÃ¤mpfen hat man durch die schiere Masse an KombinationsmÃ¶glichkeiten der ZaubersprÃ¼che stÃ¤ndig neue KopfnÃ¼sse zu entrÃ¤tseln.

4/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198139096188', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1076, 'last_played': 1581191014}
review:
The story was your standard fantasy adventure plot. It didn't wow me, but it served its purpose well enough.

The gameplay on the other hand was great, set apart from other games by a fascinating magic system. You gain four base spells and gradually learn new ways to modify and combine them until they're functionally something very different. It also allows you save multiple variations of each base spell which you can name and then tab through midcombat, though I found that less useful if I had more than 2 or 3 options built up. There was plenty of variety to play around with, but I do think the system concept could be taken even further and I'd be eager to see where it would go in a sequel.

review:
It's cute, with a fairly straight-forward storyline and the magic system is fun to play with. Fairly linear overall, but does allow for some exploration and in 'metroidvania' style expects you to go back and explore areas again as you gain new spells and are thus able to solve more puzzles.

Got it from Humble Choice and I recommend this for those looking a light-hearted, fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055879570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1581126455}

author: {'steamid': '76561198096722442', 'num_games_owned': 1704, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1581018195}
review:
The magic system has potential, but it lacks clarity, or at least more room to experiment with it to be able to think strategically about its possibilities. While the puzzle challenges encourage you to think about the spells, they only cover a few combinations. I felt like there might be a satisfying system to explore an learn in there, but very little in the world worth using that system on. 
Ultimately I think the way spells are constructed, and the number of components available, results in too many possible combinations to try. 
Usability wise, the options available for organising and recalling the spell repertoire are not sufficient, and activating different variations during combat feels clumsy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074385518', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1581313937}
review: Written by Ed Greenwood. One of the most famous authors of Forgotten Realms. Creator of Elminster. That right there should be a selling point. If not, lets talk about this spell system. It's surprisingly deep. Four base spells, each can be customized with runes. You can save multiple versions of each spell and switch between them on the fly in battle with just a button press. I took a normal fireball, gave it homing, and then added a trigger to make it recast itself when it hits something. Then I added a trigger to my shield, so that when something hits it, it casts that same fireball, that hits the enemy multiple times. And I'm only 3 hours in, lots of other runes to find. This game is charming and fun, with an addictingly deep spell system. Definitely worth a buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034779086', 'num_games_owned': 3287, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1581087063}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031190688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1580788108}
review:
The gameplay is the best part of this one. Combat is based on a spellcrafting system that is both flexible and functional, and I never found myself fighting with the controls.

The story is solid, if a bit predictable. There are definitely a number of twists and turns, but most of them seemed obvious around an hour before they actually occurred. It took me about 8 hours to beat, but I wasn't going for 100% completion. There was no padding at all, which was nice. No part of the game felt like a slog to get through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198267929467', 'num_games_owned': 620, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2341, 'last_played': 1580642253}
review:
Mages of Mystralia hat den Weg in meine Steambibliothek Ã¼ber HumbleBundle gefunden und mich in erster Linie wegen seiner Optik angezogen. Meine erste lose Assoziation vor dem Spielen war The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker (vermutlich wegen der sÃ¼ÃŸen Optik). Wie sich spÃ¤ter herausstellte war das gar nicht soooo falsch.

In Mages of Mystralia spielt man die junge "Zauberin-in-Ausbildung" Zia. Nach einer kurzen geschichtlichen Einleitung und dem tutorialartigen ErklÃ¤ren der zwei Grundmechaniken: Zaubern und RÃ¤tseln (hÃ¤ufig in Kombination) wird einem die Spielwelt Ã¼berlassen.
Warum erinnert es mich jetzt so sehr an Wind Waker? Naja zuerst einmal haben wir zwei Ã¤hnliche Konzepte: KÃ¤mpfen mit diversen Hilfsmitteln und RÃ¤tsel, die mit eben jenen Hilfmitteln zu lÃ¶sen sind. In Mages of Mystralia ist dieses Hilfsmittel die Zauberkunst. Bei Wind Waker findet man im Verlauf des Spiels z.B. das Dekublatt um Windhosen zu erzeugen - hier schaltet man im Verlauf des Spiels Modifikationen fÃ¼r einen der vier grundlegenden Zauberspruchtypen frei, der es einem erlaubt, auch hier Wind zu nutzen, um RÃ¤tsel zu lÃ¶sen. 
Mystralia wird ganz organisch im Verlauf der Story Schritt fÃ¼r Schritt zugÃ¤nglicher, indem man verschiedene Wege erlernt, sich mit Magie durch die Welt zu bewegen bzw. Hindernisse aus dem Weg zu rÃ¤umen. 
Positiv herausstechend sind auÃŸerdem ganz besonders die Speicher- und Schnellreisepunkte. Speicherpunkte sind sehr fair an Ein- und AusgÃ¤ngen der Gebiete platziert, Schnellreisepunkte sind dagegen nur in drei Stellen auf der Karte zu finden. Sie verbinden immer mehrere Gebiete durch einen zentralen Anlaufpunkt und verhindern reine Teleportsessions (wie bei Skyrim), in denen man die Welt gar nicht zu Gesicht bekommt. Mystralia an sich ist eine schÃ¶n gestaltete Fantasywelt, welche allerdings nicht Ã¼berrascht. Alles schon mal irgendwo gesehen. Die HintergrÃ¼nde, welche man hauptsÃ¤chlich Ã¼ber die Interaktion mit Statuen erhÃ¤lt, sind zwar interessant, aber oberflÃ¤chlich. Ã„hnliches lÃ¤sst sich Ã¼ber die Charaktere und Nebenquests sagen. Alles ist recht flach und generisch. Mit Ausnahme einer Quest, hatte ich nicht das GefÃ¼hl, etwas Bedeutsames und Wertvolles zurÃ¼ck zu bekommen. BezÃ¼glich der Charaktere lÃ¤sst sich feststellen, dass sie entweder Heilige oder abgrundtief bÃ¶se, schwarz oder weiÃŸ sind. Da ist definitiv Raum nach oben. Dennoch finde ich, dass die Story eine angenehme LÃ¤nge fÃ¼r die Menge an Content die das Spiel bietet hat. Sie zieht sich nicht unnÃ¶tig, macht im GroÃŸen und Ganzen Sinn und baut auch einen schÃ¶nen Spannungsbogen auf.

Die anfÃ¤nglich schon angesprochenen Zauber sind fÃ¼r mich der beste Part an Mages of Mystralia. Man hat einfach so unglaublich viele MÃ¶glichkeiten die gefundenen Runen und Elemente miteinander in Verbindung zu bringen. Das macht KÃ¤mpfe nicht nur super interessant, sondern auch abwechslungsreich. Nichtsdestotrotz kommt diese Vielfalt auch mit einem gewissen Preis: Es wird schnell zu einfach. Ich habe auf dem Archmage Modus gespielt, von Beginn an, und hatte nie wirklich Probleme. Die ersten drei BosskÃ¤mpfe waren fÃ¼r mich noch anspruchsvoll, was daran lag, dass bei wenigen ZaubersprÃ¼chen die Bossmechanik noch eine Rolle gespielt hat. SpÃ¤testens ab dem vierten Kampf fielen die Monster mir im ersten Versuch zum Opfer. Dann hat man nÃ¤mlich zum Einen genÃ¼gend Gesundheit und zum Anderen stÃ¤rkere und verschiedene Zauber, die es obsolet machen, Mechaniken zu lernen - im Endgame spammt man also nur noch diesen einen besonders zerstÃ¶rerischen Zauber und rennt weiter. Zumindest sollte das so sein, wenn man neben der Hauptstory immer fleiÃŸig alles mitnimmt und auch mal zurÃ¼ck schaut, weil man sich an dieses eine RÃ¤tsel erinnert, was man mit dem neuen Zauber jetzt bestimmt lÃ¶sen kann. Die Bosse kÃ¶nnten auf jeden Fall besser mit skalieren - so wie es alle anderen Mobs im Spiel machen, die durch stÃ¤rkere Formen und verschiedene ImunitÃ¤ten in grÃ¶ÃŸeren Gruppen hÃ¤ufig tÃ¶dlicher sind, als ein Bossmob. Dann wÃ¤re auch der spÃ¤tere Teil des Spiels noch anspruchsvoll. Ich habe es schon angedeutet: Zauber nutzt man Ã¼brigens auch fÃ¼r die verschiedenen RÃ¤tsel und SammelgegenstÃ¤nde in der Welt. Hier hÃ¤tte ich mir manchmal noch mehr Vielfalt was die RÃ¤tsel angeht gewÃ¼nscht. Ein paar RÃ¤tsel machen einen sehr guten Job darin die "Spellcrafting"-FÃ¤higkeit des Spielers zu testen, andere sind Ã¤uÃŸerst generisch und wÃ¤ren auch schon kurz nach dem Tutorial lÃ¶sbar gewesen. An der Stelle des Entwicklers wÃ¼rde ich noch mehr gebietsÃ¼bergreifende RÃ¤tsel einbauen, da die ein echtes Highlight sind!
AbschlieÃŸend mÃ¶chte ich noch loswerden, dass mir bei meinem Spieldurchlauf keine nennenswerten oder wiederkehrenden Bugs aufgefallen sind und ich die Kamerapositionierung immer sehr gut fand. Eine Spielempfehlung ist auf jeden Fall fÃ¼r alle, die RÃ¤tsel mÃ¶gen und ein etwas anderes kreatives Kampfsystem zu schÃ¤tzen wissen, drin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036458039', 'num_games_owned': 591, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1580679667}
review: Not sure if I was playing a different game than most of the positive reviews, but I found this to be a simplistic, yet frustrating puzzle game that practically lifts directly from Magicka's tongue in cheek vibe.  If it's going to take me more than 45 minutes of playtime to unlock anything more than a single button for attacking then I legitimately don't have the time to try to pry more depth out of this.  The puzzles I encountered were incredibly basic to solve, mentally, but frustrating in an unsatisfying way to actually execute.  Not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085308467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1580675348}
review:
Petit jeu Ã  l'univers enchanteur, il est trÃ¨s plaisant de se promener dans les diffÃ©rents dÃ©cors du monde. 
Le gameplay repose sur des petites Ã©nigmes bien ficelÃ©es et simples d'accÃ¨s, et des combats avec de la magie. Il est possible de modifier ses propres sorts avec diffÃ©rentes runes afin de leurs donner d'autres effets et vertus. ScÃ©nario bien rÃ©digÃ©, le tout agrÃ©mentÃ© de dialogues et quÃªtes annexes qui renforcent l'immersion.
Il est des fois de ces petits jeux qui, dÃ¨s le premier coup d'oeil d'ailleurs, me donne l'envie d'y jouer. C'est le cas avec Mages of Mystralia. Je recommande pour un moment dÃ©tente et pour dÃ©couvrir autre chose peut-Ãªtre. C'est du travail de qualitÃ© qui a Ã©tÃ© fait sur ce jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198812731450', 'num_games_owned': 2517, 'num_reviews': 342, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1580662317}
review:
Charming design, decent story and okay dialogue. 
The biggest plus is sadly the biggest minus at the same time, the spell crafting.
You have a wide variety of combinations to experiment with but the game is too short to make good use of it witch render it sort of pointless for anyone just wanting to play the game once and not continue after the story in Mage Mode.
I am, however, willing to give this game a thumbs up and a recommendation since it kept me entertained while it lasted.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967101102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1580601274}
review: So not a hard learning curve, but for those of us that want a challenge and try the perma-death mode, it's very annoying to have to go through the entire prologue that's totally unskippable.  Interesting game, but by the fourth death it's too cumbersome to get back into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069402587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1580600117}
review: Game is really unique with the way you can customize spells. My only gripe with the game is probably the lack of save points. At the very least there should have been a save point right before a boss encounter. Having to walk all the way back to the boss from a different save point really sucked. Especially since healing isn't on demand and getting hit prior to getting back to the boss means you're starting at a disadvantage already. That said, as long as you know the boss's gimmick they're not hard to beat at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995353119', 'num_games_owned': 2122, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1580596830}
review: Not sure if i'm even going to continue with this, as great as the art and sound design are. the combat is awful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067477830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 691, 'last_played': 1585742479}
review: absolutely loved playing this game. my only gripe with it, is the length of the game. I wish it was a longer game, with all of the abilities you have. If you love a good puzzle game with combat... BAM this is it. DLC or a sequel is a must for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024050686', 'num_games_owned': 3802, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1580486699}
review:
I've read some reviews about this game questioning the difficulty. I played this on mage difficulty and would recommend you do too.

[h1] Positives [/h1]
+ Combat
This is where the game shines. I mentioned this above, but you start out pretty weak, but over the course of the game you get stronger and stronger. The different augments and spells you can create are awesome. I'm sure even after completing the game that there are more fun combinations I could've made. You keep on getting augments and different elements till the end of the game. Unfortunately the cracks in the combat starts to show end game, but early to mid game it's a blast.

+ Graphics
The game look really pretty. A good use of colour. The different elements also have different sizes, travel times and damage for the same spell type. The melee ability even has different animations for each element. All these difference between the spells and elements adds just a small bit of flavour. 

+ Performance
It ran flawlessly for me. I didn't notice any slowdown. I do have a pretty beefy build tho. I got a 1070ti GPU and a 3600 CPU. I ran it at 1440p165fps.

[h1] Neutrals [/h1]
= Story
The story is alright. It doesn't do anything spectacular, but it doesn't get in the way of you enjoying the game.

= Music
Just like the story it wasn't bad, however it didn't wow me either. I, however did not mute the audio or feel the need to listen to a podcast so they must've done something right with the music. 

[h1] Negatives [/h1]
- Fast traveling + Collecting
I'm gonna bunch these two together since they affect eachother. This game is a zelda-like where you unlock more abilities that will allow you progress further. You can also upgrade your health and mana with purple soulbeads. These are hidden in the different locations throughout the world. The problem is you can only fast travel to 3 locations in the world. This means you will do a fair amount of backtracking and walking if you want to 100% the game. If you don't care to 100% the game the game becomes a lot more enjoyable. 

- Loading times
These aren't super long, but when you have to go across multiple loading screens to get to your destination it adds up. I even had it installed on an ssd which didn't seem to do much.

- Intro logos
You cannot skip these. I couldn't find any way to disable them either.

- Four spell at a time limit
Having to choose between clone, shield and dash ability feels clunky. You pretty much always want to dash so I would've liked for this to be it's own ability atleast. I know there's spell slots, but switching between these during combat feels clunky.

- Mana
I'm not sure if I'm too fond of this system. The mana works the same way stamina does in other games. It recharges at a steady rate. The reason I'm not too fond of this is because mid-late game it feels like each battle just turns into spamming as many strong abilities as possible.

[h1] Overall [/h1]
This game starts out really strong and the spell system is really interesting. If the developers would've added more fast travel locations and shortened down the loading screens I think this game would be a lot better. I would also like to see them try away with the mana system for a sequel. Due to the negatives I think I'm gonna give this game a "You should play it, but you might not love it" rating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967276134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1580297546}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051609211', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1392, 'last_played': 1580238409}
review:
[h1]Mages of Mystralia was an excellent game, and I rate it with 9.7/10[/h1]

My save was 16 hours and 43 minutes, in which I completed all the achievements and had 100% completion. 

I loved it. It was fun to play with exciting mechanics, and I would recommend it to anyone. The plot was great and how the story progressed. There are only two reasons for that 0.3 that is lost. That's why when I started the game, and I fell into the water, I died. Three seconds after I got cinematic in which I fell into the water, I swim, and I am perfectly fine :P XD that was a "ROFL" time. As for the 0.2, it's because I got stuck so many times inside walls in Lava Grotto xD Careful there guys !!! The game is tricky and has many places that you should be a bit of an observer if you want to hunt the achievements. Overall its a game for any age, and you can have plenty of fun with it even after you finish it. The spell mechanics are great!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049403221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1580572779}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990023602', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1093, 'last_played': 1580178683}
review: This is a really fun game. The spell building mechanic is very well made and there feels like there's a lot of space for creative destructive spell-age. only complaints would be that some of the puzzles are a bit fiddly to do especially when you need to ricochet fireballs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093909299', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1687412796}
review:
Took me a total of 12 hours to 100% and get all steam achievements, so overall its a short game, but fun for every minute of it. Definitely worth at least the five dollars it goes for on sales. 

The main selling point of this game for me was the spell-building system. While I think there's still potential to expand on it, the system was very elegant and fun to use. It made you want to experiment and try every combination of runes, and for the most part, there was always some exciting new combination that allowed you to solve a puzzle or get a collectible. Since the spell crafting was my favorite aspect of the game, I would love to see the mechanic expanded upon in future updates, DLC, or a sequel if they make them.

I would say the weakest part of the game is the story. The lore and world is really cool, but the actual plot is very simple. Not to say simple is bad, but it spent very little time on characters in dialogue, so it couldn't rely on them to hold up the story. I never felt any connection to any of the characters, even when the story expected me too. It's not that big of a deal, but I would just say, don't get the game for the story, get it for the awesome gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129771193', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 303, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1579657125}
review:
Cute, reasonably challenging, and enjoyable. Has some weaknesses but overall I'd recommend it to adventure game lovers. It reminded me a bit of Zelda games personally (though I really don't play anymore, so Zelda fans may disagree with me). The spell system is pretty unique and the most flexible I've ever seen. If you're a creative type you can make some pretty interesting spells. If you're more like me, you can find some in guides/online/etc.

Pros:
- Nice art style
- When you are behind something there's an outline of your character so you can still tell where you are
- The spell system is *extremely* flexible, letting you invent some pretty awesome spells.
- Despite having a fixed camera, the angle was  usually pretty good

Cons:'
- The story never caught me emotionally, I never felt invested in it. I think they could have done much better here
- A certain part of the ending that was supposed to be a surprise was actually pretty predictable
- Having a map that zoomed in on the local area would be nice

Verdict: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198041604853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1710, 'last_played': 1578291897}
review:
A beautiful and fun game. The customizable magic system is clever, if a bit limited. My only complaint is that it feels short. Short games aren't intrinsically a problem, but this one feels like the story it wants to tell needs more time.
This is well worth your time if you like puzzle adventures like Zelda. I'm going to be watching this developer because I think they have enormous potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000713444', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1579899696}
review:
I really hate having to give this a negative review. It has glimpses of a really great game, but there's a number of things i just cant get over.

1) Unskippable cutscenes
2) Horrible difficulty curve; easy is ridiculously easy, and hard is unfairly hard
3) Questionable save/checkpoint system; might not be so bad if it weren't for the two above issues
4) Fights are always the same; they throw too many guys at you at the same time so you can't prepare any of the "good" spells that take a moment, and your shield uses up a huge amount of your mana bar per block so you run out quickly. 

One of the other reviews gave a more in-depth breakdown and its worth reading theirs too. Its a real shame; the magic system is neat, i love the "assemble your spell" concept, but the truth is the way combat is structured, i can barely use most of the interesting combos because by the time i cast it, i've been attacked for half my health bar. Theres no invuln frames after getting hit from what i can tell either, so if 4 guys gang up on you, you're dead real fast. Which happens ALL. THE. TIME.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120506877', 'num_games_owned': 573, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1009, 'last_played': 1579831011}
review:
Mages of Mystralia has a lot of charm and a somewhat interesting preemies coupled with an interesting and unique magic spell crafting system. However despite this it is held back by awful controls and a less than stellar combat system
 
The controls feel like you are driving a tank, you move slow and turn slow. this isn't at first a bad thing, but it quickly becomes apparent that the game expects you to move fast when dealing with enemy attack and some puzzles. you are given a dash, but this uses mana and has a lot of end lag which removes all your momentum, which again defeats the purpose of a movement ability.
 
The poor controls truly shines in combat, which this game has a lot of. The game gives you 4 different base spells to use, only 2 of which are useful in combat, these  being the fire ball (Once you have access to the movement mod) and the Ice spell. the melee attack  does poor damage and is laggy, letting enemies kill you quick. also casting any spell locks you in place, which makes dodging a nightmare. The enemies are interesting and the 4 bosses that i have beat have all been cool, but I find myself wondering why the enemies have better attacks and movement options then the main character.
 
These are just a few of a handful of complaints I have with the game, but the best way to see if you like the game is to play it for yourself

author: {'steamid': '76561198010526514', 'num_games_owned': 1188, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1002, 'last_played': 1579629509}
review:
[h1] Overall [/h1] 75/100
[h1] Game length (100% Achievement) [/h1] 17 hours
[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 8/10
[h1] Graphics [/h1] 7/10
[h1] Story [/h1] 6/10
[h1] Notes [/h1] 
Being able to make your own spells really attracted me to this game and is what kept me interested as I hunted down new runes to find out what kind of new spells I could make. Some of the puzzles with the runes were a bit tough to figure out as understanding what a specific rune does with different types of magic is tough if you don't thoroughly explore it all.
I enjoyed the story in the beginning but was a bit disappointed as it got further in. It fell into one of those collect each of these 4 things in these different areas story to get you to different areas which isn't entirely bad just makes for a boring story for a while. The problem is that it is near the end of the game and after you finish that part of the plot...[spoiler] it throws you into a boss fight. I thought this fight was going to end up being the boss before the final boss but they ended up cliff hanging the story a bit. [/spoiler] I was still also missing quite a few runes when I finished the story which isn't too bad but I wish they had after story things to work on so that the runes got a little more use while I was finishing up my 100%. Achievement wise it is a pretty easy 100%

author: {'steamid': '76561197982658491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 1258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1161, 'last_played': 1580186566}
review: Pretty cute zelda-like spellcaster game. Has a lot of weird difficulty spikes, but overall a pretty fun experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055684398', 'num_games_owned': 1281, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 1068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1068, 'last_played': 1579513811}
review: Beautiful game and fun too. Its Zelda meets Transistor plus magic.  Only things I would do different would be adding a few more obstacles and enemy types that need certain runes to be overcome.  A steal for the ~2.33$ I paid.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971397219', 'num_games_owned': 1553, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1579493526}
review: This was a fun (but short) magic casting adventure where you must solve puzzles to unlock runes and elements, and then create and customize your spell book to save Mystralia! I loved the spell-building concept and can't wait to see more of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313839700', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1578925732}
review:
No puedo decir que no me haya gustado el juego, porque no he podido jugarlo.
A pesar de estar renderizando 60fps el juego me daba la sensaciÃ³n de no ofrecer mÃ¡s de 20. PensÃ© que serÃ­a cosa mÃ­a, pero despues de marearme y estar seguro de que aquello no era normal lo he desinstalado.
No se si a otros os pasarÃ¡ lo mismo o es cosa de mi tarjeta grÃ¡fica, que sea incompatible con algo de este juego, pero nunca me habÃ­a pasado.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992459465', 'num_games_owned': 1043, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1579348144}
review:
My playtime roughly equals an 80% run. I did not bother to find all the collectibles or puzzles and went to the final boss as soon as I could. I think you can probably squeeze at least 10 hours out of it by going for 100% completion.

I liked the ability to craft your own spells and the environmental puzzles that required you to figure out what kind of spell you need to solve a certain challenge. The story was okay but somewhat predictable so there would have been room for improvement. I played on the normal difficulty and found it a tad too easy. Probably very suited for younger children. I did not try the harder difficulties but I imagine them to present a bigger challenge (if their descriptions are correct).

author: {'steamid': '76561198041415164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1579308634}
review:
Es un juego con muchas referencias a los juegos de Zelda. La mecÃ¡nica es muy parecida e incluso en ocasiones los grÃ¡ficos.

La estÃ©tica es bastante infantil. Los personajes, colores y animaciones son simples pero efectivas. Personalmente hay algo que no me acababa de convencer... es como si hubiera algo por pulir. Sin embargo, como decÃ­a antes, es efectiva.

Las mecÃ¡nicas pueden resultar algo complejas a veces, sin embargo la dificultad del juego escala de una manera muy llevadera. No llegas a atascarte en ningÃºn punto, pero si que te supone algunos retos.

La trama... es bastante simple, en su mayorÃ­a con clichÃ©s con algÃºn que otro giro. Eso sÃ­, el final me dejÃ³ bastante descolocado.

La opiniÃ³n global es que es un juego agradable y entretenido, aunque no imprescindible. Recomendado para aquellos que no busquen un juego muy largo y que les dÃ© muchos quebraderos de cabeza. A relajarse y disfrutar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048502586', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1158, 'last_played': 1579281135}
review:
A friend gifted it to me. One of the most fun games I played.
Tinkering with spells makes you feel like a mad scientist, thinking a little than throwing stuff at the wall to see what sticks.
When you finally figure out your "wipe" spell you feel like a God. 6-12 enemies surrounded you? No problem because they are already dead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076666158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1580795913}
review: Great exploration adventure with an intriguing magic mechanic (build your own spells by linking effect runes in different ways). Marred a bit by uneven difficulty ("Mage Mode" won't challenge anyone over the age of 10, but Archmage frustratingly highlights all of the game's rough edges: laggy movement, BS boss attacks and "freeze" effects, and bizarre design decisions on the health system (why does it autosave when I use the one-time healing item? Why does it always require backtracking across the game world to refill? We're not all looking for a Souls experience...) Nevertheless, it's a worthwhile pickup on sale (or in Humble Choice this month!), with the right blend of nods to beloved classics (2D Zeldas, Alundra, Dungeon Master magic system) and distinctive innovations that you'll remember for a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969208810', 'num_games_owned': 4056, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1579193028}
review:
The spell combination is what really sets this game apart, you can create really crazy spells with each new spell element you find and the puzzles are a good way to figure out how to use them.
That's the limited mana you can't really break the game that much since you can trigger another spell after another and that would make the game too easy.
Although I didn't find a really cheesy spell combination it was very late in the game and it was a hidden spell element.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029423256', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1579121074}
review:
I really liked the way you craft and customize your spells.
There are some fun puzzle mechanics but at some point I realized the reward isn't worth it for me most of the time, some green currency I didnt really use and another purple one to upgrade your health and mana (Felt not worth it), on top of the fact that sometimes you can't even do them because you don't have the neccessary runes.
I dislike the fact there is no local map of where you are, i'm just lost sometimes and had to backtrack (Enemies respawn when loading in areas, might also be the reason I wasn't too bothered unlocking all things). 
Most of the difficulty comes from the amount of mobs and stuff they throw at you. 
Overall I did enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981588360', 'num_games_owned': 880, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1577489692}
review: I've played 5 hours, gotten (what I think) is halfway and I have absolutely no desire to play more.  It'll briefly scratch that Zelda-itch, but it's very shallow.  It's kind of neat that you can build new magic, but it's just not very interesting or fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198407510469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1062, 'last_played': 1578892564}
review:
17+- hours 100% not really difficult.
I have to say its one of the best experience i ever had :) highly recommended
not like traditional action rpg, kinda tactical as well
pretty characters and game design, ui polished well, easy to grasp, very deep mastery...
love the improvising and play around with the magicks XD
please make mages of mystralia 2 oh beloved devs

author: {'steamid': '76561198046731487', 'num_games_owned': 2298, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 1786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1641437613}
review:
I set my difficult to hard, which is proving to be quite a challenge. But overall, very fair and entertaining.
The core of the combat is the ability to customize your spells and then prey on enemy weaknesses.
The storyline is a bit lacking in innovation, but it's good enough. The game is very linear. You can go back to old areas, but the only reason is to collect all the items.
As you progress in the game, new tougher enemies will start to spawn in older areas, leaving the entire map to be a place to tread carefully. The puzzles can be challenging at times, I've had to look up a couple of them online. Overall, just a really good fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996425216', 'num_games_owned': 542, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1578851278}
review:
Lovely art, story and music ruined by horrible level design, enemy design and systems design.  You are constantly thrown into situations as a ranged character where enemies swarm you, boss fights where the space doesn't suite the encounter and a spell system which is so lazily taught that you often don't know what to use for any given situation. 

What is worse is that even though you are a mage you get no self focused Aoe Spells with knockback/stun, no radial/perfect shield, no teleport, no healing spell. Most puzzles have one solution and the whole game feels like a kids game but plays like a hardcore game. I quit twice out of frustration and that was after looking at some guides to give it chance. Maybe I was the issue here, maybe I could create spells with better triggers or gets better later on. By the lava dungeon I started to notice the awful trends getting worse. Less space in combat arenas, more swarms with stun lock and body blocking and no new needed tools to deal with the added mobs. If you feel like you must play this game go try out Magicka or one of the other 1000 Diablo clones. This isn't worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062537225', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1578777511}
review:
Honestly its not my cup of coffee however its most certainly my cup of tea though, quite a nice game to play on the lowest setting to chill with for a couple hours here and there.
You can challenge yourself with the harder modes but honestly its do damn cute why do you want the stress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059235610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1578957904}
review: The game is a good platform game with an intriguing spell system. You can add runes to basic spells, modify them as you will and save them. Some elements are really interesting story wise but it feels a bit unpolished on that side. I wish it had more of a Terry Pratchett humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027044677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1602909879}
review: Great game! Cute, fun, and really does make me feel like I'm using actual problem-solving and spell creation to beat puzzles on the fly. Very enjoyable, not super-challenging if that's your desire but there's always hardcore mode!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038786881', 'num_games_owned': 484, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1578543925}
review: What a gem! I enjoyed this game so much! DonÂ´t let the half-ass 2d art fool you: this game is beautiful, clever and super fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984832804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 928, 'last_played': 1578600778}
review:
This is a great little game. The gameplay reminds me a lot about Magicka but the spell casting system is much better. Combining different runes to achieve different spell effects is a lot of fun, especially as you have triggers that can activate new spells when conditions are met. In a way the rune system is more like the old classic game Legend from 1992 which probably has the most fun magic system created in any game.

The graphics is nice, the music is quite pleasing, the controls and spell casting work as they should even playing with mouse and keyboard but unfortunately the story is quite simple and predictable. Still, it didn't stop me for enjoying this so if you like customisable spell casting just go ahead and try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048873008', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1147, 'last_played': 1578569489}
review:
Story is pretty nice
The spell creation is actually really fun (and can be expanded more than that too)
The final boss might have been much easier than expected, given most of the other bosses, with some mobs actually being harder than that

author: {'steamid': '76561197973134525', 'num_games_owned': 6153, 'num_reviews': 834, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1578917827}
review:
El juego me ha sorprendido enormente.

La trama esta muy bien hilada, sencilla pero bastante interesante. 

Los escenarios son geniales, ni muy grandes ni muy pequeÃ±os, no hay demasiados ya que es un juego indie pero cumple enormemente. En cuanto a la variedad de enemigos, aqui quizas peque bastante, ya que no hay un gran numero de variedad pero los que hay varian entre si (colores) indicando sus resistencias.

Los puzzles, no hay gran variedad, pero los que hay se van complicando lo suficiente como para acerte pensar unos minutos.

La magia, la magia es algo que me ha encantado, cuatro elementos variables entre si y editable con mas de una vientena de runas que haran que sus hechizos sean completamente diferente unos a otros y te den una resolutividad en el combate genial. Cuenta con la posibilidad de guardar hasta unas 6 configuraciones diferente para poder elegirlas dependiendo del combate o del puzzle que te enfrentes.

Finalmente un juego genial, quelo hacen una de esas joyitas indie que no deben faltar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000879653', 'num_games_owned': 2704, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1578628793}
review:
This review is based off what I assume to be "medium" difficulty. The other options are story difficulty, which I assume is deliberately easy, and permadeath difficulty, which I don't hate myself enough to attempt blind in any game.  I'd honestly recommend that most players play on story, I'll explain why below. If I could give this game a neutral review I would, but I'll give it a negative to at least make this review visible to people like me who look at negative reviews to find out what the potential downsides of a game are.

Combat is awful, the difficulty appears to be just throwing about a dozen guys at you at once so you can't spend any time actually dealing with any of them, and there's no way to heal [i]at all[/i] in this game unless you get lucky with random drops from breakable pots or you equip a late-game item that heals you for a pittance whenever you deal damage and is mutually exclusive with the items that let your attacks ignore damage immunities.
The block move leaves you vulnerable to being surrounded, hit from above or below, or hit with power attacks, while the initial dash move is interrupted by colliding with any enemy, has a dead stop at the end that lasts long enough to negate its purpose as a space clearer, and doesn't have any iframes.
Your initial melee attack has pitiful range, while the first upgrade to it you get (Overcharge) lets you charge it and boosts its range. However, charging it is basically never an available option with how fast attacks come at you, and just having the charged attack equipped not only makes your uncharged melee slower but you take a step back every time you use it, meaning you can no longer stunlock enemies.
I ended up taking more damage when using it than not, with the result that I was stuck with the basic attack until I unlocked explosions quite some time later.
Also, your offensive and defensive measures all use the same energy pool, which would be fine if it didn't have such a long delay before it regenerates and enemies didn't come in such high numbers and require so many hits to take down. There are energy meter refills available, but they are only available in a single location, the number you can carry is limited by how many of a collectible you've found, and each individual refill costs money. Grinding money in this game is painfully slow since most enemies don't drop any of it, and while you don't have a lot of things to spend it on, there is a sidequest that requires you to fill your wallet completely and then spend it all on a single item. This means you're heavily incentivized to never use the energy refills until the end of the game where you probably don't need the refills anymore, negating the whole point.
This all ends up making the early game (pretty much up until right before boss 2) an enormous pain to get through, and improvements are incredibly slow even after that.

The combat system doesn't actually approach decency until you finally unlock element swapping and can do things like dodge through enemies while leaving an afterimage.
However, to do that you have to beat boss 3, which is absolutely infuriating because you're stuck on a platform barely big enough to fit you and have to take coordinated ranged attacks from all sides simultaneously. Your shield only works in one direction, the platform's way too small to dodge on, and running around to try to get the ranged shots to miss is a gamble at the best of times. It's kind of a shame, because the other half of the boss fight is ingenious and incredibly fun.
Also, even once you actually get element swapping, the dungeons just start forcing you to fight a dozen guys at once in rooms filled with death pits who all either have homing attacks with incredibly long durations, ground target attacks that proc additional random ranged attacks when they hit the ground, or can outrun you even with the speed boosted dash, so...have "fun" with that.
Once you unlock all your elements as well as the Ether and Teleport runes, the combat system ends up actually being quite fun, since you can mix and match your skills to get some intense synergy and can make your melee and ranged attacks spawn on top of your enemy. Unfortunately, the game's basically done at this point - all that's left is clearing the arena, finding all the collectibles you missed, and doing the final dungeon.

Puzzles aren't great either. There's exactly one class of puzzle that lets you have hints in exchange for money, and they're all tremendously easy provided you have the tools unlocked, which you find out from the hint marker without having to pay.
The tile puzzles, where you have to match up all the arrows on the nodes, are stupid hard but have no hints available. Which would be fine if it weren't for how you need every rune puzzle upgrade you can get to not die.
The challenges that don't have hint markers or tiles are a bit more unique but that doesn't necessarily make them better.
One challenge is a combat challenge against about a dozen enemies on a platform barely big enough to fit all of them, and one of the enemies is one of the giant beetles that charges you which you can't shield and have to dodge, but even if you had the dodge that goes through enemies at this point the platform's too small for you to use it anyway.
Then there's the bird puzzle, where you have to match a sequence of musical notes. I had to look the solution up, because apparently the notes were supposed to be different colors but they were all the same color to me.
Additionally I was absolutely convinced that note 5 was lower than note 4, but it was supposed to be higher, so it was genuinely impossible for me to solve this on my own.
The reward wasn't even really worth it at the time, it's a moderate magic cost reduction in exchange for the spell behaving highly erratically. The only effect I could find that didn't result in an unusable spell was the overcharge effect, and I already mentioned why that doesn't work. Eventually you unlock the Ether rune mentioned above which lets you gain the cost reduction at no penalty, but again as mentioned this happens pretty much at the end of the game.

As for the story...it's ok. Nothing amazing, nothing terrible, and it ends on a cliffhanger. It's interesting enough to keep going even with the broken combat system. I'd say this game's worth your time, just play on easy so the combat encounters don't lead to your monitor being broken by a thrown controller.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086995968', 'num_games_owned': 1410, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1578351394}
review:
On the easiest setting, this is a pretty relaxing and fun game. There are boss fights and so far are not overly difficult. The boss fights have their own unique pattern / fight style (which are really fun to play).

The spells are pretty cool too. You only have 4 spells active at a time, but you can augment the spells as the game progresses, and even make a spell invoke one of your other spells.

You could do far worse than this game if you are looking for a casual game to pass time. Worth the asking price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000642871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1578275038}

author: {'steamid': '76561198075202999', 'num_games_owned': 814, 'num_reviews': 333, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1578192345}
review:
absolutely not
you'll notice my small play time
it's because the game has unskippable cutscenes 
in this day and age
in the first screen that I could "play" i was immediately interrupted by another unskippable cutscene where my character fell through a plank and swam through shore
no relevant story telling there, no reason why it couldn't be playable

I lost my faith in the devs in almost record time
so that's impressive I guess

author: {'steamid': '76561198035811848', 'num_games_owned': 1797, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 1315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1681805376}
review:
You get the same feel you get playing the older Zelda games, except you are a mage with a bad ass spell building system. My mind was blown away with the possible spell combinations. I spent a lot of hours just messing with spells already lol.

Post game and 100% review: Just like the Zelda games only, if Zelda was a girl and belonged in Hogwarts. This game is insane fun and a total diamond in the rough. I loved every minute and hope to be able to purchase a sequel some day. 

My overall rating: 9.8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198104647655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1099, 'last_played': 1563156685}
review:
TL;DR: a really stellar, unique magic/combat system coupled with a solid story make this indie RPG where you play a young mage coming into her powers in a repressive society not one to miss.

There's a lot to like here. The story and world are relatively well-developed. The NPCs and areas change as the story progresses. I also love the little comic that the dev has available on their website to read up on the backstory. The art style is distinctive and colorful, despite the occasionally heavy subject matter. The soundtrack is lovely. And the best darn thing is the spell system--you have four core spell types, and you slowly discover ways to modify how they work, which yields a ton of fun combat options and solutions to the MANY puzzles littered throughout the world. In general, I enjoyed the puzzles themselves as well, as they varied in difficulty and style, and the game is generous with hints if you need them.

In terms of weirdness, there are some errors in the dialogue, a few glitches (none that are game breaking), and some dangling/confusing story threads at the end. There is effectively no post-game--none of the NPCs react to you doing your duty and saving the world, even though they reacted to everything else you did. I also don't love that most of the "voice acting" is just grunts and nonsense sounds over text bubbles. 

However, this is a sweet little 10-15 hour experience to near completion, and definitely worth full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032112530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1562876142}
review:
I really enjoyed this game all the way through. The spellcrafting system is great giving you so many ways of completing the different challenges.

Only downside is controls with keyboard and mouse sometimes weird/difficult to aim but nothing game breaking. The game recommend playing with game pad but since I don't have one I wasn't able to test if that's better/easier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034199687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 333, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1563057362}
review:
Great indie zeldalike.

So yeah you're an apprentice mage. You find spells and modifiers and combine them later to make like a cascading homing splitting fireball. You solve little riddles to get pearls where you need four to upgrade life or magic. You can explore a little bit and have to backtrack some like in a metroidvania or zelda type game. 
There's no quest log only a marker for the main mission like in the golden nineties.

On the standard difficulty the game is easy to relax from your Sekiro or Souls session. The second difficulty is there for replay value I guess.
Music is nice, story is mildly interesting without breaking new fantasy ground but yeah your mind can relax from trigonometry too.
Playtime was a hand-crafted 8 hours, semi complete. Of course if you're going to explore everything get all the wands and all that maybe 10.

Only negative point is load times and poor optimization for a game that seems not so heavy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198428518240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1187, 'last_played': 1562527057}
review:
A unique action-adventure game that has plenty of challenge and charm. From combat to puzzles, how much thought and creativity you put into the spells crafted from what runes you have available to you makes all the difference in achieving your goals. That being said, gameplay is open-ended, and even puzzles have a number of different solutions that require varying rune combinations.

If I were to criticize anything, it would definitely be the intro cutscene. Perhaps the art style was a conscious decision, but to me it simply looks like a colorized draft of an FMV rather than the final cut. This, I fear, sets a poor first impression for the game. This, combined with the game's slow start (which would otherwise not be a problem in my opinion), might cause some player's to give up on continuing before reaching the point in which the spell customization really opens up a few hours into the game and allows the game to show its true colors.

Beyond that, I had no complaints with the game. It possesses an intriguing story, well-designed combat encounters and puzzles, and countless spell combinations that I could hardly believe the developer trusted me to possess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198337870226', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1475, 'last_played': 1562001694}
review:
Fun, great looking levels/scenery, puzzles that are interesting throughout the game and even some hidden stuff.
If you liked RPGs back in 80s and 90s then this game is a great next gen RPG.
Normally I don't bother finishing many of these games but I found this one to have all the right mix of fun, adventure, puzzles, story telling, NPCs to chat with, and freedom to run around, make decisions and all with great visuals.

For me this game almost seems like a homage to Zelda, Neutopia, Ys, Secret of Mana, etc
But all the while it has its own story, look, and feel that is highly compelling to play so I'd highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096230835', 'num_games_owned': 1161, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1561949167}
review:
Such a truly fantastic game.
My largest problem with most games, both video and tabletop or card based, is that the magic system felt restrictive.
You can make 500 spells to choose from, but unless there is the option for the player to fiddle with the elements and make the spells unique, it feels just like any other system.
The ability to combine different elements, cast spells together or change directions is fantastic.
Being forced to combine all the options you have to complete puzzles by turning or multiplying or changing the type of spell to make bridges or storms really stretches the mind and in no way subtracts from the story or the combat elements.
The combat is similar in that you can alter the spells, however you may not want to mid-combat, so there is the ability to rotate your favorite spells to overcome different resistances or beat cover or specific mechanics.
Can not recommend enough, I hope they add to the game or make another because I loved every moment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104392527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 334, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1532496676}
review:
An unexpected hit for me, though I wish it got more attention. [i]Mages of Mystralia[/i] is a top-down action/adventure game where you fight your way through areas and dungeons entirely using magic. But the unique aspect of this game is that you can craft your own spells!

The mechanic is by far the most appealing thing to the game, though it takes a bit to get used to it. It uses a grid-based system where you connect Runes to amplify your spell, add extra elements, or perform different actions. For instance, you can have a basic fireball attack that shoots one ball straight forward. Or you can create a spell that launches a row of fireballs. You can add Runes that make the fireballs bounce off of walls, or home in on enemies, or turn in mid-air. Or you can create a spell that causes a close-ranged fire explosion. Or you can even trigger another elemental attack immediately after the fireballs hit an enemy, or have the spell cast itself again after a condition... And so on!

There's quite a bit of variability in what you can do, though of course that's only as you progress and find more Runes and abilities. Plus, some combinations turn your spells into utility spells, like the ability to create ice platforms on bodies of water, or to simply freeze enemies in place temporarily, or putting up a magical shield for protection. The more you add onto a spell, the more that your Mana (magic bar) will be used up. But the Mana automatically recharges itself over time.

Besides getting new abilities for spell creation, you're able to find different wands that give you buffs or increase the attack damage of specific elements. Further, you can find upgrades to spend to increase your HP or Mana. Besides all of that, I don't remember much else, but the spell system is the main focus.

The story follows you being a fantasy hero (or an underdog almost, in this case) in order to protect the good magic users as the kingdom has banished them and is looking to get rid of them. You navigate a few NPC areas, and head through dungeons fighting sets of enemies and bosses as in a typical fantasy game. And of course, there are some puzzles for you to solve to get items or upgrades, some of which may only be available if you create specific spells.

The game lasted me about 12 hours to complete everything, so it wasn't a bad length. I wasn't quite sure what I was getting into at first, but after I went through the first few areas, I was hooked. Plus, the more I was able to create, the more fun I had. I definitely recommend giving this game a try!
